headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the 2010 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Tom Cleves, you may begin your co
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the 2010 Fourth Quarter and Full Year Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Tom Cleves, you may begin your conference.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melissa. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our fourth quarter earnings conference call today. Our speakers this morning are John Faraci, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Nicholls, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Off
componenttext:
Thanks, Melissa. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining our fourth quarter earnings conference call today. Our speakers this morning are John Faraci, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Nicholls, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
During the call, we'll make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. These are outlined on Slide 2 of the presentation. We'll also present certain non-U.S. GAAP financial information. You can find a reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures on our website. The website also contains copies of the fourth quarter 2010 earnings press release and the slides that we'll use today. And with that, I'll turn the call over to John.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everybody. If you let me just start up by saying we finished 2010 with a strong quarter. Earnings were almost $0.60, almost 3x what they were in the fourth quarter last year. It's really backed of solid volume and price plus
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everybody. If you let me just start up by saying we finished 2010 with a strong quarter. Earnings were almost $0.60, almost 3x what they were in the fourth quarter last year. It's really backed of solid volume and price plus performance. Margins is important, it expand 240 basis points quarter-over-quarter, and we had very strong earnings in our Ilim joint venture in Russia. 
Moving to the next slide and put this in context. The fourth quarter for International Paper was the strongest fourth quarter that we had in over 10 years. I don't say that to suggest that we're anywhere near our peak, we think we've got quite a bit of run rate ahead of us as we go to 2011, which we'll talk about in the call.
So turning to full year results for a minute, the strong fourth quarter rapped up a very good 2010. We really had International Paper a V-shaped recovery while the economy in the U.S. at least was recovering in more of a U-shaped. Our low tide mark was the first quarter where we earned $0.05, and we came out of the year with a lot of momentum with third quarter and fourth quarter performance. 
Earnings for the year were more than twice than they were last year, just over $2 compared to $0.88. Free cash flow of $1.7 billion, margin expansion of 110 basis points. So we kind of ended the year with more margin expansion than we have for the full year, which is a good jumping off point for 2011.
And significant return on investment improvement, which we'll talk about. More debt reduction and pension funding and two increases in the dividend of one earlier in the year and one late in the year now restored the dividend back to $0.75 from the $0.10 it was coming into the year. 
2010 headlines. Sales up 8%, again both volume and price, strong free cash flow even with higher levels of capital spending in 2010 compared to 2009. And sales growth was also took -- that capital took about $800 million of cash. And we still had a strong free cash flow. Less than $9 billion in debt, $4 billion reduction in debt over the last several years as we completed the warehouse acquisition, that's close to over 40% reduction in our debt and a healthy cash balance of just over $2 billion. And I think this all demonstrates that International Paper can generate very healthy cash flow and still what I would characterize as a recovering, not yet fully recovered economy.
Just the next slide shows you where the revenue growth is coming from. I think it's important because it underscores the global balance is becoming more and more part of International Paper. In our North American business has performed well and sales growth was up 6%. Outside North America, sales growth was doubled what it was during North America, 13% and in our Ilim joint venture, our revenue growth and volume the price of 33%. So we included Ilim in the whole package of it, our revenue growth outside North America was 3x what it was inside North America.
And again that's both volume and price. And turning to the waterfall chart that shows you the EPS comparison of 2009 and 2010. The big lever that stand out here price, volume, cost and Ilim. And the one negative and it was a substantial negative, but we're able to overcome it during the year and still expand our markets we had input cost pressure, primarily Wood and OCC of over $1 a share. 
So International Paper is a cash flow story and continues to be a cash flow story. Post-transformation plan in International Paper, and build a step change capability in our free cash flow and this slide here shows that. We've more than doubled our free cash flow, pre-transformation from an average of about $900 million a year to $1.9 billion, if you look at the last three years. And this has obviously flow-through through our ability to improve our return on investment, which is a key metric for International Paper. We come out of 2010 going into 2011 with our returns as we see in the cost of capital zone. Our run rate, ROI, third and fourth quarter was about 8%, that's twice its low point of 4% in the middle of the recession in 2009. 
And from a macro perspective, I think I would characterize 2010 as a transition year, not nearly a mid-recycle year because when we look at our Industrial Packaging business, our Container Board business, xpedx are three big businesses in North America. We don't see demand yet back to pre-recession levels, eventually they will get there.
So Tim, I'll turn over to you.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. I'm on Slide 12. So I'm going to start with the fourth quarter and go through a few more of the details. And you can see on this slide sales growth year-over-year of 9%. Also look at the EBITDA, we had in the t
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. I'm on Slide 12. So I'm going to start with the fourth quarter and go through a few more of the details. And you can see on this slide sales growth year-over-year of 9%. Also look at the EBITDA, we had in the third quarter over $1 billion of EBITDA, but we also had the land sell and it was a fairly light outage quarter. So what I feel really good about looking at third quarter to fourth quarter, if you adjust for the land sale and you adjust for outages, we would have been about $960 million of EBITDA in the third quarter and a very solid $870 million in the fourth quarter. Another good quarter of cash flow, as John mentioned and in that cash flow number of $600 million, there's $130 million of incremental CapEx spending in the quarter. So a really strong way to finish the year.
If you look at the next slide, just going from third quarter to fourth quarter, I think you look at and say the momentum continues. We had more outages in the quarter. It seasonally slower volume quarter, and we did have a few operational issues late in the quarter while we ran very well in the third quarter. And then in the fourth quarter, as the season changed and cold weather has some impact, we had a few one-off items in some of the mills, which we've now recovered from. But we'll probably last around $50 million on the table from the items that we had. 
Price was another good story. In a lot of the businesses, Box was up, export pricing was up. Consumer Packaging business at price increase through the fourth quarter, as well as our European Paper business. And if you look at volume year-on-year, we were up in our Packaging businesses, PNC was down, which we would have expect in North America and Brazil continues to perform very strong. 
The one item on tax that I do want to call out, our tax rate in the fourth quarter dropped to 28%. And I think the way to think about that is there was legislation in the fourth quarter in the Extenders Bill that we could not book as we would have normally booked throughout the course of the year and so it was a catch-up in the fourth quarter, and that's basically for the R&D tax credit that we received as well as how some of the offshore interviews are treated from U.S. tax perspective. 
So in summary, it's a good quarter, volume was where we expected it to be. Prices were up. Operations were good. But could have been better and inputs were trending slightly higher. So if you go to the next page, I've got a breakout on input cost. And the thing that I take away from this is good performance with inputs going out, more than half of inputs were in our North American business and more than half of the input increases were in Industrial Packaging. So OCC, up $17 million quarter-on-quarter. We did see wood fiber continue to improve and really for the first time, we saw chemical start to jump up as well. 
So that, let me turn to the businesses and I'll start with Industrial Packaging. Solid quarter, we had much higher maintenance outages in the quarter and some of the operational issues that I've mentioned earlier showed up in IPG. And as I said, it's now been resolved. Volume was down seasonally, but up 2.8% year-over-year and box prices moved up $4 and we continue to see export pricing increasing. So when you turn to the next slide. We've shown you this slide before on margins. We saw our fourth quarter margins in line with the highest margins in the industry. And I think a really important point, as we exit 2010 fourth quarter, EBITDA margins that are 240 basis points, better than the full year average for 2010.
We also saw earnings improved not only in North America but in our European business, our two largest Industrial Packaging businesses that had improved performance since 2010. Specifically in North America, we had to work through a pretty significant input cost increase. The bulk of that being OCC. But with close to $400 million of increase inputs, we still improve the business by $100 million. And we ran in the second half of the year at an average margin of 19.5% versus the 12% in the first half as we were dealing with the input cost. 
International container had a great year. In Europe, volume was better by $20 million and our cost was better, largely due to the Etienne mill shutdown, but good performance across all of the business units there. If you turn to printing papers. I thought printing papers had a very good quarter. Operationally, we ran, well in North America we had a couple of issues outside North America, but the step down in performance on us was right in line with our expectations around moving from a warmer season to a colder season.
As I mentioned, price in Europe was up. We were stable in the U.S. We did have about $11 million of green energy credits that did not come through. This is in our Poland mill and it's just the timing issues, so we should pick those up in the first quarter. So overall, our printing papers had a solid quarter and a really good year. If you look at Slide 19, you can see the margin improvement across all of the businesses starting with North America, very stable performance moving from 19% EBITDA margins to 20%. Just a huge amount of improvement in Europe. And it came from demand recovering in a strong way and prices moving up throughout the year and also good operations throughout the year.
And Brazil did a very good job managing its export price. On average, prices through the year were up about $150 a ton. If I turn to the Consumer Packaging business, it ran very well in the quarter also. And if you adjust for the outages basically had a similar level of earnings in the fourth quarter than it had in the third quarter. Backlogs continued to be strong in our food and paper business. We continue to have backlogs that go out about four weeks. That's about a week better than what we have last year and our year-over-year volume in the fourth quarter was up 9% versus 2009. We also as I mentioned earlier, got about $15 a ton more in price than the third quarter. So all in all, a really solid quarter for the Consumer Packaging business.
If you look at the next slide, I'm showing you what happened through the course of the year. And the low margin level in the first half was really a result of what happened with the wood shortage and the fiber cost increases that happened at the end of 2009 and the beginning of 2010. But a great job recovering from that and also realizing the announced price increases throughout the year and improving us. We've had a couple of mills where we had operational issues for a number of years and second, third and fourth quarter just showed sequential improvements in mill operations for the business. So the business exits 2010 in the fourth quarter 230 basis points better than the full year average.
By turning to xpedx, a lower number than expectations but for a couple of reasons and I'll go through those. The good news is the business is continuing to recover. And in the fourth quarter, we had our strongest revenue quarter. If you look at average daily sales for the whole year. So first half of the year was 10% lower than how we ended up in the second half of the year on revenue. And total year EBIT move from $55 million in 2009 up to $78 million in 2010. Part of the reason for the lower earnings number in the fourth quarter is that the business has been undergoing a strategic review of business improvement opportunities. And after having completed most of the work, decided to take some charges for business segments that will be exiting in the retail and printing equipment segments specifically. And we're completing the work this quarter. So we'll have a lot more to talk to you about the earnings improvement run rate when we release first quarter earnings.
If I turn to the Ilim joint venture, another good quarter building on the third quarter's results. And if you remember, we report Ilim on a one quarter lag. So what you're seeing is our fourth quarter number for Ilim's third quarter. And we have to go back and think about what was happening with pulp prices in the second quarter of this year. We did see a step down in pulp price from the second quarter to the third quarter and then it began recovering during the third quarter but did not fully make up the decline for the quarter. That continues into the fourth quarter. And so we expect Ilim's performance to continue moving up. They had good operations and also the $31 million results that we booked as equity earnings included a $12 million charge for an asset write-off related to a vacant office building that they're no longer using. So that was a one-time item that impacted their third quarter, our fourth quarter. 
When you look at the three-year history of the Ilim joint venture, we finished 2010 EPS accretive than we have record earnings for 2010. And over the three-year period, after having a good year, the first year of the joint venture and then being hurt by the economic crisis in the second bounce back and we're now at earnings levels that are above the pre-crisis level. We've also, since the time of investment received $152 million in cash dividend and the projects, the strategic investment projects are currently underway and on track.
Before I shift from the businesses to other corporate items, let me just touch on Europe for a moment. Europe, as we exited the year for the company, we were approaching cost to capital, Europe was at cost in capital all year long. And had a really strong performance across all of the businesses. Our Russian Paper business, Western European Paper businesses and our Container business, which is in Europe, Middle East and Africa. And ended the year with an ROI of 16%, basically on good demand recovery, good operations and really good price momentum.
So with that, I'll switch to debt. And on Slide 26, you can see where we were at the end of 2008 with $12 billion of balance sheet debt and a $3 billion pension gap. And you see the waterfall to our results at the end of 2010 with $8.7 billion of balance sheet debt and $1.5 billion pension gap. That pension gap is made up of about $1.1 billion gap in our qualified plan and a $400 million gap in the non-qualified plan. So when we look at this, we say, hey, we've made a lot of progress on debt reduction, but we're just getting to the threshold of the targets that we had set for ourselves.
On a capital spending front, we're estimating that in 2011 we will spent somewhere between $1.2 billion and $1.3 billion on capital. That's after averaging $650 million on capital for the 2009-2010 period. And it's going to really come from the results of higher maintenance and higher regulatory. You can see that on the chart, which is primarily related to the boiler mac requirements. But we're also increasing spending on cost reduction projects and strategic projects. The cost reduction projects, where we're going to spend about $200 million more incrementally than we did in 2010 are primarily around consumption reduction projects and lowering our cost base. The strategic and the biggest one is really the Sun joint venture, our coated board machine that we announced last year, which there'll be a fair amount of spending on that this year.
So with that, we're higher in this year the average that we set over the cycle, but we're still right in line with the billion-dollar target of spending on average across the cycle. And we're still committed to that target. So let me end up on Slide 28. And I think this is a good example of what we mean by cost reduction capital. If you look at our energy efficiency progress since 2000, we've reduced our dependence on fossil fuels purchased energy by 45%. Currently, we spend $1 million-plus on purchased energy a year and the capital projects that we have pursued over the past decade are not very large project. In fact, if you look at the 10-year period, we've completed close to 1,000 project over 10 years. So they tend to be smaller, smaller dollars, quicker to implement and quicker payback. The one area of opportunity that we think we still have in our legacy mills, we have more opportunity to reduce consumption of purchased energy. But we have a bigger opportunity of the warehouse our mills, where we just started implementing some of these projects. So with that, I'll wrap it up and turn it back over to John.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, Tim. Let me just quickly summarize again the fourth quarter. I think the slide here and I'm looking at Slide 29 says it all. It was a good end to 2010. Again, I think we had a V-shaped recovery in our earnings performance and cash flow performance a
componenttext:
Okay, Tim. Let me just quickly summarize again the fourth quarter. I think the slide here and I'm looking at Slide 29 says it all. It was a good end to 2010. Again, I think we had a V-shaped recovery in our earnings performance and cash flow performance and kind of a U-shaped economic environment certainly North America. 
If we turn to the first quarter outlook, I guess I'd say it's January. It's seasonally slow like it's always is in January from a demand standpoint. You think the first quarter kind of looks like the fourth quarter. On all fronts, things are more or less stable with the exception of fiber and energy, where we see some increase in cost, and we do see some improvement in the Ilim joint venture because we're in that one quarter lag. But by and large, kind of a stable and seasonally slow economic environment is in the first quarter. No surprises there.
The 2011 outlook, I think is quite positive. It's for a full-year basis, we're quite positive, secret momentum. We think about 2011 as a breakout year. 2010 was a transition year coming out of the worst recession we've had in 70 years. In our view is strong earnings improvement. ROI improvement and cost of capital zone and strong free cash flow to go with it and global balance with all parts of the world contributing to International Paper. I think we'll stop right here, Tom, and take questions.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttextpreview: Could you give us a bit more color on what benefit you think you might be able to get from the energy conservation project within the warehouse and legacy mills?
componenttext: Could you give us a bit more color on what benefit you think you might be able to get from the energy conservation project within the warehouse and legacy mills?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We had good opportunity. I'll give you a great example one that we're implementing this year and it would be on water conservation. And in our pulp mill IP, we've really optimized the recycling of water through our washers. And in the warehouser system, t
componenttext: We had good opportunity. I'll give you a great example one that we're implementing this year and it would be on water conservation. And in our pulp mill IP, we've really optimized the recycling of water through our washers. And in the warehouser system, they had not been doing that. So we're talking, George, about a project that's $4 million investment with a 50% plus ROI. And Valliant's first up for that. So if you kind of scale that across the system you could see that's pretty sizable. So really a lot of the energy projects are around the technologies, some things we put on our boilers and in the pulp mill and of course we'll continue on conservation. So I think it's still a good opportunity for us to improve the bottom line.

componenttext: There are not all 50% payback projects, I wish they were. We've got a good pipeline. It's not that good. You will get $100 million a year, and you got to do that to offset all the cost that go up. You have to put your capital work at least even if you want to get ahead.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Strategically, I maybe taking a different tack, given the containerboard and the present business that become very good return in businesses from the action that you've taken over the last five years, but also given the fact that they're fairly mature. Wh
componenttext: Strategically, I maybe taking a different tack, given the containerboard and the present business that become very good return in businesses from the action that you've taken over the last five years, but also given the fact that they're fairly mature. What do you think it means for the future in terms of you've committed to the $1 billion in capital spending target over the course of the cycle. But do they think perhaps that might be lower not higher? And similarly, given the cash that you're generating the business, it would be a time that you started to get the leverage up sort of an overall improve the return that you provided to your equity holders?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Corrugated paper into that is in North America, that's a big important business for International Paper and it's also in the content capital zone and it add Europe, which includes Russia, Eastern Europe and Western Europe as well. So they're not all matur
componenttext: Corrugated paper into that is in North America, that's a big important business for International Paper and it's also in the content capital zone and it add Europe, which includes Russia, Eastern Europe and Western Europe as well. So they're not all mature businesses. But to your point, we recognize those businesses as what they are. They're large markets. We've got good positions in them. We're going to stay with them and I would say that $1 billion is what we think capital spending would be to do two things. Take advantage of those cost-reduction projects, and we think we're pretty good in identifying and doing this stuff. And also keep our facilities competitive. And that's very important in any business, whether it's a mature one or broad one. As far as leverage goes, we're committed to balances in cash and we've given you our debt target is relatively to EBITDA and obviously if EBITDA goes up, we've got more debt capacity and we'll see how that plays out over the next several years. But we like where we are.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from Gail Glazerman with UBS.
componenttext: You're next question comes from Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Carol, can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of packaging both in terms of export demand and pricing. And also in the past, I think you talk about some contracts, false contracts that would reset in the new year. Should we expect to
componenttext: Carol, can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of packaging both in terms of export demand and pricing. And also in the past, I think you talk about some contracts, false contracts that would reset in the new year. Should we expect to see a little bit of incremental pricing from the 2010 initiative than the first quarter?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: On the packaging demand, John talked about it, it is seasonal. Although I would say that in January, our actual January volume on a year-over-year basis continues to trend up on the same pattern that we see. December date is out now and December was up 3.
componenttext: On the packaging demand, John talked about it, it is seasonal. Although I would say that in January, our actual January volume on a year-over-year basis continues to trend up on the same pattern that we see. December date is out now and December was up 3.5%. So we would continue see modest year-over-year growth on U.S. packaging demand. Relative to export, export demand is still remains still solid. If you look at all economic indicators, there's global growth in all regions, and we continue to participate in that and that's a strategic segment for us. I think it has been publicly acknowledged there has been some downward pressure on expert pricing in the fourth quarter due to some seasonal supply that became available. But I can't speculate on future pricing. But my outlook for supply demand is that as the U.S. hits the seasonal strong second quarter, married up with strong maintenance outages, that the seasonal balance will get tighter. But overall, I think things are in very good balance with inventories, demand and pricing right now.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gail, what makes us feel positive about the outlook and the outages is that these industry numbers now. Since the first part of 2008, box demands fell by 9% across the U.S. industry. It's up coming around, it's up 4% in 2010. So we're still 6% down from p
componenttext: Gail, what makes us feel positive about the outlook and the outages is that these industry numbers now. Since the first part of 2008, box demands fell by 9% across the U.S. industry. It's up coming around, it's up 4% in 2010. So we're still 6% down from pre-recession levels and the economy is recovering. It's recovering at a slower rate [ph] , but it's recovering. So we see good demand run rate for these businesses in North America, whether it's paperboard, whether it's industrial packager, whether it's xpedx, as the economy continues to recover.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we're going to tell you a lot more in the first quarter about what the plans are. The business has been working for about the past four months on looking segment by segment and how they're going to position themselves in the market and around produc
componenttext: Well, we're going to tell you a lot more in the first quarter about what the plans are. The business has been working for about the past four months on looking segment by segment and how they're going to position themselves in the market and around product lines and they're competing that work and once we see the completion of that work, we'll know what the upside opportunity will be and what the expected cost to achieve it will be.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: A good news story. It's not a one-year implementation. But over the next two, three years, we've concluded there's a lot more earnings run way in xpedx than we thought there was.
componenttext: A good news story. It's not a one-year implementation. But over the next two, three years, we've concluded there's a lot more earnings run way in xpedx than we thought there was.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, just two things. When we look at your earnings in the Industrial Packaging business outside of North America, you don't have the same balance there that you're starting to develop in your Printing Paper and Consumer businesses. And obviously you've
componenttext: John, just two things. When we look at your earnings in the Industrial Packaging business outside of North America, you don't have the same balance there that you're starting to develop in your Printing Paper and Consumer businesses. And obviously you've talked about your North America and hesitate to be. But can you give us a sense of how important it is to use strategically to build up the Industrial Packaging profitability outside of North America and whether you're looking for the same kind of contribution there that you're getting in printing papers and consumer?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, remember, Mark, that the Industrial Packaging business outside North America is only boxes. And the integrated business, the margins are much large we ran an integrated basis and dissected the margins are much larger in the mill system than they are
componenttext: Well, remember, Mark, that the Industrial Packaging business outside North America is only boxes. And the integrated business, the margins are much large we ran an integrated basis and dissected the margins are much larger in the mill system than they are in converting system. So frankly, our non-U.S. box business in Europe outperforms our U.S. box business, which is a whole lot larger on return on investment basis. So we really like the position that we developed over there, which is concentrated in southern Europe, northern Africa and through [ph], which is a line of broadbase business. But we also like being a net buyer recycled board in Europe as well.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Does that mean we should expect you to be looking to grow that business overseas as much as? I'm really trying to get a sense of how important it is to you?
componenttext: Does that mean we should expect you to be looking to grow that business overseas as much as? I'm really trying to get a sense of how important it is to you?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is pretty impressive. Box volume in Europe was up 7% in the fourth quarter compared to the fourth quarter last year. In Turkey, our box volume I think was up 20%. So we're growing that business organically, which is obviously the most profitable and
componenttext: This is pretty impressive. Box volume in Europe was up 7% in the fourth quarter compared to the fourth quarter last year. In Turkey, our box volume I think was up 20%. So we're growing that business organically, which is obviously the most profitable and best way to do it. And if we have an opportunity to make a bolt-on acquisition that fits our financial criteria, we would look at it. But we don't feel we need to be in the board business.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: One more question on fiber. You mentioned fiber pressure. When we think about Q1 of last year, obviously there was a ton of fiber pressure because of the weather. Are you getting a sense we're developing that same sort of problem at this point?
componenttext: One more question on fiber. You mentioned fiber pressure. When we think about Q1 of last year, obviously there was a ton of fiber pressure because of the weather. Are you getting a sense we're developing that same sort of problem at this point?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, not on the wood side. OCC prices obviously are trending up. But our wood cost are doing the opposite. They don't come down very far in the winter time because of weather. But we've recovered a lot of wood cost escalation and kind of stuck in it right
componenttext: No, not on the wood side. OCC prices obviously are trending up. But our wood cost are doing the opposite. They don't come down very far in the winter time because of weather. But we've recovered a lot of wood cost escalation and kind of stuck in it right now. So residual chip supply has come back on. We probably can't bring wood cost down a whole lot further. But it will get better as the first quarter moves into the second quarter as the weather impact.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Virgin fiber peaked in the late April, early May timeframe last year, Mark and continued to follow through the year. So I think we picked up $6 million in price improvement in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter.
componenttext: Virgin fiber peaked in the late April, early May timeframe last year, Mark and continued to follow through the year. So I think we picked up $6 million in price improvement in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you look at Page 61 on the appendix, Mark, you'll see that where we got our fiber cost trends.
componenttext: If you look at Page 61 on the appendix, Mark, you'll see that where we got our fiber cost trends.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from Anthony Pettinari with Citi.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little more about uncoated freesheet volumes. North America look like it was down about 12% year-over-year. Could you give us a little color on that decline? Was it below expectations? Did it meet expectations? And are
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little more about uncoated freesheet volumes. North America look like it was down about 12% year-over-year. Could you give us a little color on that decline? Was it below expectations? Did it meet expectations? And are there specific segments, mail, commercial printing, cut size that are doing better than others?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll let Mark Sutton, who is here, Anthony, who runs our Printing Papers business in North America as well as Brazil talk to that.
componenttext: I'll let Mark Sutton, who is here, Anthony, who runs our Printing Papers business in North America as well as Brazil talk to that.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's a great question. The year-over-year minus 12 that's shown on that slide, a portion of that for us is exported quite a bit more in fourth quarter of '09 than we did in '10. We also had less capacity as we've shut down the Franklin mill. Outside of th
componenttext: It's a great question. The year-over-year minus 12 that's shown on that slide, a portion of that for us is exported quite a bit more in fourth quarter of '09 than we did in '10. We also had less capacity as we've shut down the Franklin mill. Outside of that, our experience in International Paper price tracks very close to the market. And that basically is a market that's down a little over percent 2010 over 2009. Underneath that, a good recovery in the printing grades, continued slight decline in the cut size paper and kind of a mixed story in envelopes and converting. Forms are down and envelopes and other forms of converting papers are flat to slightly up. So our experience mirror that pretty well.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So when you think about North American uncoated freesheet volumes declining into 2011, is it appropriate to think about that as sort of low-single digit decline or?
componenttext: So when you think about North American uncoated freesheet volumes declining into 2011, is it appropriate to think about that as sort of low-single digit decline or?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've said before, we believe the structural decline is in that 3% range. But we still believe there's some recovery that can occur, and we think we could see even a flat year or a year that look very much like 2010, which was for all practical purposes f
componenttext: We've said before, we believe the structural decline is in that 3% range. But we still believe there's some recovery that can occur, and we think we could see even a flat year or a year that look very much like 2010, which was for all practical purposes flat in 2011. There has been virtually no recovery in about 45% in the market, which is the cut size paper, part of that we think is driven by the employment picture. So our view is probably better than mid-single digit decline. We're looking hopefully at a flattish market.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chip Dillon with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chip Dillon with Credit Suisse.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe you did say this, but if we were to look at the actions in xpedx and I'm looking more short term I know there's some long term, things you're looking at. You're down $22 million from the fourth quarter of '09. Would you say that represents the amoun
componenttext: Maybe you did say this, but if we were to look at the actions in xpedx and I'm looking more short term I know there's some long term, things you're looking at. You're down $22 million from the fourth quarter of '09. Would you say that represents the amount of the cost you incurred or would have been something more or less than that?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's not all the cost we incurred.
componenttext: That's not all the cost we incurred.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you would have done better year-over-year if you hadn't done sort of these actions?
componenttext: So you would have done better year-over-year if you hadn't done sort of these actions?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We could have. You have to recall last year, we had ship in the fourth quarter a LIFO benefit. So it's just accounting. But if files the numbers a little bit. It made us look a little bit better last year than we otherwise would have.
componenttext: We could have. You have to recall last year, we had ship in the fourth quarter a LIFO benefit. So it's just accounting. But if files the numbers a little bit. It made us look a little bit better last year than we otherwise would have.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The thing to look at xpedx chip is its revenues per day, that's the key indicator and then our operating expenses. Revenues per day prior to recession were $30 million a day. They fell to $25 million. Fourth quarter it was $28.5 million. So revenues fell
componenttext: The thing to look at xpedx chip is its revenues per day, that's the key indicator and then our operating expenses. Revenues per day prior to recession were $30 million a day. They fell to $25 million. Fourth quarter it was $28.5 million. So revenues fell 19%, they're up 13%. But they're still down to pre-recession levels and our operating expenses are back in the 80% range, which is where we wanted them. With that equation, with sales come back, we'll be making some pretty good money. And we kind of concluded, we have more earnings runway there in the next couple of years than we thought we had from a margin standpoint.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I guess shifting gears. When you look across your businesses, certainly the margins and pulp and paper and containerboard while they're not back to say to where we've seen in the past, they're well on their back. But [ph] , which is typical is kind of
componenttext: And I guess shifting gears. When you look across your businesses, certainly the margins and pulp and paper and containerboard while they're not back to say to where we've seen in the past, they're well on their back. But [ph] , which is typical is kind of lagged a bit. And as we look at 2011 versus 2010, would it be fair to expect that Consumer Packaging to maybe show more of an improvement than maybe the company average? Do you think of it that way just because it has lagged and prices have just more recently started to move up there?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'll let Tom Kadien comment on that. He runs that business.
componenttext: I'll let Tom Kadien comment on that. He runs that business.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chip, there's a slide in the deck that shows kind of first half, second half improvement in EBITDA margins. And you're spot on, we expect to be able to sustain that improvement and actually build on that 2011. The backlogs are good. We had high wood cost
componenttext: Chip, there's a slide in the deck that shows kind of first half, second half improvement in EBITDA margins. And you're spot on, we expect to be able to sustain that improvement and actually build on that 2011. The backlogs are good. We had high wood cost in the first half and we also didn't operate that well in the first half than we had a lot of price flow-through. And we had a very much improved second half and we're going to do better than that in 2011.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chip, the trick in cutter paperboard is get the mix right or run the mills well and get the commercial side and pricing rates and do all three at the same time. And we know how to do all three. We haven't done all three at the same time well until recentl
componenttext: Chip, the trick in cutter paperboard is get the mix right or run the mills well and get the commercial side and pricing rates and do all three at the same time. And we know how to do all three. We haven't done all three at the same time well until recently. We've now had two quarters of getting that right. As Tom said, our EBITDA margins in that business can be as good as they are in Industrial Packaging and printing papers.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You had I guess several quarters or couple of quarters of experienced with the SCA plant that you bought in China. And can you talk a little bit about how that's going versus your expectations? And maybe as an add-on, what do you think is going to happen
componenttext: You had I guess several quarters or couple of quarters of experienced with the SCA plant that you bought in China. And can you talk a little bit about how that's going versus your expectations? And maybe as an add-on, what do you think is going to happen in terms of the Board dynamics over there whether it's quality or price given that the increasing tightness of OCC?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Tom Kadien again. I've got the Asia business. SCA is turning out to be exactly what we thought it would be from an asset standpoint and customer standpoint. The business was in worse shape than we would like when we close on July 1. The containerb
componenttext: This is Tom Kadien again. I've got the Asia business. SCA is turning out to be exactly what we thought it would be from an asset standpoint and customer standpoint. The business was in worse shape than we would like when we close on July 1. The containerboard pricing ran up significantly over in Asia, if you recall OCC pricing in the second quarter, and we had over 20% run-up in our input cost. On the IP side, and our legacy plans, we recovered that. In the SCA side in the second quarter they recovered zero of that. So that's what we walked into on July 1 when we close. We've been trying to rebuild those margins. We had some shutdown costs of redundant facilities, cheap plants primarily. So the numbers weren't very good. It didn't meet our expectations in the first six months that we owned them. But we're already seeing price improvement, if we look at our fourth quarter Delta P on the SCA plant, we were net positive versus again higher containerboard pricing in China. So we're gaining on it and we still think it will be exactly what we thought it would be when we bought it. The market right now, we're in Asia for containerboard is kind of quiet. We're in the middle of Chinese New Year. But we think it's going to be -- we think OCC is relative stable. Carol, you have a better view of that. But we think containerboard pricing is going to remain high, and we still have margin to recapture and rebuild particularly at the SCA plants.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'm talking about the supply volume, what's impressive about China is the volume growth. We got our legacy plants and the opportunity for the SCA plant.
componenttext: I'm talking about the supply volume, what's impressive about China is the volume growth. We got our legacy plants and the opportunity for the SCA plant.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: The puzzling part, and our legacy plans are boxed sales year-over-year were up 30% in China. And on the SCA side, it was low-single digits. On the price side, we recovered about 16% out of the 20% of the containerboard increase and on the SCA side, it was
componenttext: The puzzling part, and our legacy plans are boxed sales year-over-year were up 30% in China. And on the SCA side, it was low-single digits. On the price side, we recovered about 16% out of the 20% of the containerboard increase and on the SCA side, it was low-single digits. So we know what the gap is and we know how to improve it.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: So we've got a lot of runway there, chip.
componenttext: So we've got a lot of runway there, chip.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from Rick Skidmore with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: You're next question comes from Rick Skidmore with Goldman Sachs.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: On your slide for the first quarter outlook, you have to the red square on higher fiber and chemicals, is there anyway you can provide some color around potential magnitude of that?
componenttext: On your slide for the first quarter outlook, you have to the red square on higher fiber and chemicals, is there anyway you can provide some color around potential magnitude of that?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Higher. Well, oil has backed over $100 a barrel. So that's probably a little higher than we thought when we put this together. OCC, Tom said looks like it's may have begun sideways it could be a little bit lower but still going to be higher than in the fo
componenttext: Higher. Well, oil has backed over $100 a barrel. So that's probably a little higher than we thought when we put this together. OCC, Tom said looks like it's may have begun sideways it could be a little bit lower but still going to be higher than in the fourth quarter number for sure. So the two drivers of the margin are demand for OCC in China, which we can't predict with what the certainty is. Weather, with half of the country under two pieces of snow and use more energy and shipments are not the rate is going to be higher.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the magnitude on chemicals, are you seeing significant chemical increases since the ground acrostic?
componenttext: And the magnitude on chemicals, are you seeing significant chemical increases since the ground acrostic?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Some uncostic, some starch and there's some offsets going the other way. But the meaningful pieces there are the energy-related costs will be freight consumption of the mills. We're not heavily dependent on oil, but mostly gas and what we see on fiber. An
componenttext: Some uncostic, some starch and there's some offsets going the other way. But the meaningful pieces there are the energy-related costs will be freight consumption of the mills. We're not heavily dependent on oil, but mostly gas and what we see on fiber. And if fibers stay where it is, it's going to be higher than the fourth quarter number.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then John, you talked in your prepared comments that IT was a free cash flow storage. You talked about balanced approach use of free cash flow between debt and shareholders and M&A over the last couple of years. And 2010 most of your cash was for debt
componenttext: And then John, you talked in your prepared comments that IT was a free cash flow storage. You talked about balanced approach use of free cash flow between debt and shareholders and M&A over the last couple of years. And 2010 most of your cash was for debt reduction and pension with a little bit to the dividend. Did you see that balance shifting away or a little bit more tilted towards shareholders or M&A in 2011? Or do you think it's kind of a third, a third, a third? Or how should we think about the use of cash?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think you should think of it as balance. We've been on a very consistent path over the past couple of years. You mentioned debt. We're just now hitting the threshold of the target debt that we're aiming for. If you look at the dividend, we took it from
componenttext: I think you should think of it as balance. We've been on a very consistent path over the past couple of years. You mentioned debt. We're just now hitting the threshold of the target debt that we're aiming for. If you look at the dividend, we took it from $0.10 to $0.75, and we've said we're on a path to restore it to where we were before the crisis. We're going to spend some on capital this year, we think that's the right thing to do. We've kind of held back on good, solid projects over the past couple of years. And investment, if we see selective investments that meet the criteria, and will strengthen the business that we have then those are opportunities to. So I think, it's balance and we want to look at that balance, Rick, over time and not try to get ourselves into a hard formula because opportunities don't come that way.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a follow-up on the M&A side. Given the significant free cash flow that you see in your business in 2011, you see a relatively sizable pipeline or do you see a meaningful pipeline of M&A opportunities that provide the same type of cash retur
componenttext: And maybe just a follow-up on the M&A side. Given the significant free cash flow that you see in your business in 2011, you see a relatively sizable pipeline or do you see a meaningful pipeline of M&A opportunities that provide the same type of cash return opportunities as buying back your stock given the free cash flow that you've seen in your business?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rick, let me just drop in and say I think Tim has said it very well. We're committed to the balance sheet of -- does because our be cash flow strong, a to have a big M&A pipeline. That's not the case at all. If we see things that can make International Pa
componenttext: Rick, let me just drop in and say I think Tim has said it very well. We're committed to the balance sheet of -- does because our be cash flow strong, a to have a big M&A pipeline. That's not the case at all. If we see things that can make International Paper better and meet our financial criteria and  businesses we're in, we have been looking at things like that, and we'll continue to do so. And the balances of cash isn't quarter-to-quarter, it's over time. So as we pay down debt, obviously we're going to be opportunistic looking about buying back repaying debt early in the opportunity present itself so. If we have free cash flow that we don't think we see opportunities for, the thing to do is to look for ways to effectively get it back to shareholders.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: You're next question comes from Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, just to start up. The number on CapEx was a little bit higher than I expected for 2011, higher than I thought I was hearing you guys hinted a couple of months ago. I wondered a, was there any rollover from 2010 into 2011? And also incrementally, what
componenttext: Tim, just to start up. The number on CapEx was a little bit higher than I expected for 2011, higher than I thought I was hearing you guys hinted a couple of months ago. I wondered a, was there any rollover from 2010 into 2011? And also incrementally, what hit did you really added over the last few months?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's pretty much in line with what we've been thinking. There's always a little bit of a carryover. One of the items is the board machine in China, which took a little bit longer for us to get ourselves organized and get permits in place to make sure we'v
componenttext: It's pretty much in line with what we've been thinking. There's always a little bit of a carryover. One of the items is the board machine in China, which took a little bit longer for us to get ourselves organized and get permits in place to make sure we've got of our docs on the row. So that's going to shift from 2010 into 2011. But it's also just managing a pipeline that we had drawn down significantly in '09 and '10. And during the course of '10, we start of building that pipeline up in terms of product development. So as I said, we're going to average $1 billion over the cycle. We've been at $650 million average the past couple of years. And this by no means takes us above average of $1 billion number. We can spend $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion this year and next year and still be right on that target. So I think we're being very consistent with what we've said.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we don't know is what the boiler mark spending is going to be this year because we don't know the regulations are. And there's a pretty big swing there and that's why we're telling investors that the $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion is probably where we'
componenttext: What we don't know is what the boiler mark spending is going to be this year because we don't know the regulations are. And there's a pretty big swing there and that's why we're telling investors that the $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion is probably where we're going to end up. We usually give you more specific number, but we've just don't know what the regulatory spending is going to be.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: You raised China. And China, I wondered if you could take a minute to step back and is kind of compare your experience, Russia versus China. You got big joint ventures in both places. And from the outside, it seems like Russia maybe actually going a littl
componenttext: You raised China. And China, I wondered if you could take a minute to step back and is kind of compare your experience, Russia versus China. You got big joint ventures in both places. And from the outside, it seems like Russia maybe actually going a little bit better?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: There are two very different markets. Somewhat of may two years ago that you can't lose a lot of money in China unless you're there. So we've got to remember that. So we've been pretty selective in what we do. China is a very, very competitive market. And
componenttext: There are two very different markets. Somewhat of may two years ago that you can't lose a lot of money in China unless you're there. So we've got to remember that. So we've been pretty selective in what we do. China is a very, very competitive market. And Russia is competitive too. But there aren't many competitors in Russia and doesn't competitors in China. So the capacity additions in China, whether it's cement, steel, you name it, buildings or paper are significant. So it's all about supply and demand. For different reasons, it's tough to be successful in both those markets. I would say that part of reason doing better at Russia is because we're selling to China. 2/3 or not 2/3, 80% of what Ilim makes is for export and 90% of that goes to China. So in a way, the two are related. But the operating environment is very, very different. Russia is a tough operating environment. But a different set of regions.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Tom just a little bigger perspective, when we went through the waterfall, still one of the biggest levers was just pricing movement. And I just wondered, now as the economy kind of starts to return toward normal, is there anything you can do in you're
componenttext: And Tom just a little bigger perspective, when we went through the waterfall, still one of the biggest levers was just pricing movement. And I just wondered, now as the economy kind of starts to return toward normal, is there anything you can do in you're businesses going forward to reduce that pricing volatility and to perhaps just create more stable earnings, more stable cash flows?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've been pretty consistent, Mark, talking about matching our supplies to our demand. And we think that is the discipline that we need to have and we'll continue to have. But at roughly 70,000 tons of downtime in the fourth quarter again to match supply
componenttext: We've been pretty consistent, Mark, talking about matching our supplies to our demand. And we think that is the discipline that we need to have and we'll continue to have. But at roughly 70,000 tons of downtime in the fourth quarter again to match supply and demand. And if you look back, I don't want to try to forecast prices because I can't and I shouldn't and I won't. The pricing over the last cycle, which is the most severe cycle than we had in 70 years. The pricing volatility in each board and paper and containerboard was a lot less than they've ever been in the prior cycles we're it's nearly severe because of a think supply, demand management.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just wondering, John, you're trying to change the nature of kind of customer relationships particularly in the Packaging business? Maybe make it a little more, create a little more stable pricing or maybe mechanisms that task cost on the customers mor
componenttext: And just wondering, John, you're trying to change the nature of kind of customer relationships particularly in the Packaging business? Maybe make it a little more, create a little more stable pricing or maybe mechanisms that task cost on the customers more efficiently?

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, all customers are different. They have different business models. We have different business models. Our experience is with type of input cost we have, having certainty around pricing without having certainty on input cost is got a lot of downsides
componenttext: Well, all customers are different. They have different business models. We have different business models. Our experience is with type of input cost we have, having certainty around pricing without having certainty on input cost is got a lot of downsides to it. And the flip side is also holds true. So if we can match pricing to cost and get certainty on our margins, that would be something we want to consider.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. We had some downtime in the fourth quarter. I think that's also maybe one of the lexicons we probably need to not talk about. We ran our mills to our demand and that resulted in an operating rate of 94%. We had outages. So that meant that we ru
componenttext: Yes, Mark. We had some downtime in the fourth quarter. I think that's also maybe one of the lexicons we probably need to not talk about. We ran our mills to our demand and that resulted in an operating rate of 94%. We had outages. So that meant that we run everything because we didn't need to. And the math would say that that was about 80,000 tons of production that we did have orders because of the seasonal demand. The snowstorm of this week is definitely a big event. We had a lot of box plans as most of the country through the Midwest starting all the way over from Kansas, all the way up through to the Northeast. And we've had sizable portion of our system that's been down yesterday, today. And my guess is that we could lose a day or so of aggregate production through that. What really matters is our customers. We need to run when our customers start their factories and plants back up, whether we put back whether they have at the capacity call it back to have to see. But one day out of 20 a couple weeks is sizing it up.

And for us, I'd say it could be one day. So think about that as 4% February impact to us.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's Tim. Let me start with the credit, I can't actually do what you're suggesting simply because there's a lot of variables that are in play and let me go through a couple of them. You mentioned earnings. We could assume what First Call says and move fro
componenttext: It's Tim. Let me start with the credit, I can't actually do what you're suggesting simply because there's a lot of variables that are in play and let me go through a couple of them. You mentioned earnings. We could assume what First Call says and move from there. But there's other factors. There's the possibility of pension contributions that could get away on that. There's also the issue of whether we determined at the end of the day, we think the alternative fuel mixture credit is a taxable credit or a non-taxable credit. And there's some reason to believe that the proper conclusion maybe non-taxable. If we come to that conclusion, then economically it just doesn't make sense to refund or payback the credit that we've already received and apply for the CB credit. So we've got more work to do, it's going to take us into 2011 to really nail down where we think we are. And what we took in the fourth quarter was just the benefit on black liquor gallons that we ran in 2009 but did not mix. So those were never applied for the alternative fuel mixture credit. And in the first part of your question was what again?

componenttext: We've been right around $100 million in terms of cash taxes the past few years. It's not a huge step up, but we do expect to see an uptick over the next year or two.

headline: International Paper Co., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2011
