componenttext: Good morning. My name is Lori, and I'll be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Tom Cleves, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lori. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining International Paper's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are John Faraci, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Nicholls, Senior Vice President and
componenttext:
Thank you, Lori. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining International Paper's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are John Faraci, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Nicholls, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mary Laschinger, Senior Vice President and President of will also participate in today's call. 
During the call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. These are outlined on Slide 2 of the presentation. We will also present certain non-U.S. GAAP financial information. A reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures is available on our website. The website also contains copies of the first quarter 2011 earnings press release and today's presentation slides. I'll now turn the call over to John Faraci.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and just before I get started as you're moving off to another assignment shortly, thank you for your work with Investors over the last 3 plus years.
componenttext: Thanks, Tom, and just before I get started as you're moving off to another assignment shortly, thank you for your work with Investors over the last 3 plus years.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you John.
componenttext: Thank you John.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: For the first quarter, we characterizes a good solid quarter for International Paper. The momentum that we talked about with you last year started to build in the second quarter 2010 continues. 1 of the things that really made a difference for Internation
componenttext:
For the first quarter, we characterizes a good solid quarter for International Paper. The momentum that we talked about with you last year started to build in the second quarter 2010 continues. 1 of the things that really made a difference for International Paper, has made a difference and continues to make a difference is our global products. And as we talk about our performance during you'll see that global balance really starting to pay off in our results. First quarter were solid returns again and the cost of capital range of operating EPS of $0.74 versus $0.04 a year ago and up 18% sequentially quarter to quarter. During the quarter, as you know, we also increased our dividends for the third time and increase it slightly above prerecession levels. Entering the quarter, we announced strategic entry into the India paper and packaging markets. 
So just turning to that slide for a brief financial snapshot before I turn it over to Tim. Sales were up 10%. We improved EBITDA margins up 400 basis points over to first quarter, 60 basis points over the fourth quarter, continued very strong free cash flow, and first quarter that always is and was seasonally weak, this was impacted by quite a bit of bad weather in the January-February timeframe. Continued debt reduction and continue to have a strong cash balance on the balance sheet. So with that, I'll turn it over to Tim to take you through the first quarter and some more details.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. As John said, we did have a very strong quarter in the first quarter, but not without some headwinds. Volume was seasonally weak. We are typically slower in Russia, slower in Brazil, slower in North America but we di
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Good morning, everybody. As John said, we did have a very strong quarter in the first quarter, but not without some headwinds. Volume was seasonally weak. We are typically slower in Russia, slower in Brazil, slower in North America but we did have weather-related impact in North America that hit us as well and I'll speak more about that when i come back to the Industrial Packaging business. We also had higher input cost and I'll speak more about those in details but we are really carried by the strength of our operations and it wasn't just here in North America, it was really around the world. The other notable item on this page was the really strong result from Ilim and I'll share some more details with you in just a few minutes about their fourth quarter, our first quarter reported. 
If you turn to Page, we've got our normal input cost breakout and we had close to $50 million in the first quarter. It was really in line with our expectations weighted towards North America. We had about 80% of the increase in North America and 20% in Europe. The Packaging business is we're able to cover the input cost increases with operational improvements, Printing Papers was hit disproportionately in the quarter by energy chemicals and I'll talk a little bit more about that when we get to the Printing Papers segment. 
So let me turn to each of the segments now and I'll start with industrial packaging. We had a really solid first quarter even with the weather impacts and the rising cost. We had purposely pull back a little bit on export shipments towards the end of last year for the first quarter anticipating higher box demand in the U.S. and then the weather gotten in the way but I think it was the real strength of the business was able to react quickly, take the market-related downtime that they needed to and so if you look about the volume buckets there 10 million of that 14 million was really related to market-related downtime around North American box. Had very solid operations, really across all the mills and converting facility not just here in the U.S. but globally. 
Turning to the next page, look at margins. In North America, the ability of the business to really react quickly led to the highest margins in the industry in the first quarter. If you look at the blue bar. And if you look at the shifts, the Delta between the green which was first quarter last year and the blue first quarter this year, we have the largest improvement year-over-year over 900 basis points. I think the real strength of the business and our ability to react quickly is highlighted on the next page where we are really different from most in terms of how we're positioned across multiple channels to market. And you can see in the green boxes we're integrated to a level of about 80% that includes both the U.S. channel and our box brands overseas. And we have about 20% of volume going to the upper market. Both here in North America and in the export channels. And really what the business is doing is focusing on the right channel mix, period by period to maximize value and that focus has led us to be a consistent long-term supplier in all of these channels over time. 
Last slide on North American Industrial Packaging on the next Page, is just some data point to highlight the strength of the quarter. It's not our seasonally strongest quarter, it's probably our seasonally weakest quarter because of our heavy orientation to the agriculture packaging and that's really a second quarter event. But we had a really strong quarter with improved margins and part of that margin improvement has come from the realization of price increases from the announcements that we made last year. If you look at year-over-year, first quarter to first quarter, we've realized just over $90 per ton in price increases. So we feel really good about that. We also generated cost of capital returns in the first quarter running at an operating rate of 93%. So the way we think about it, we look at it we say, hey there's still some earnings runway here. We took almost 100,000 tons of market downtime in the quarter and still have a cost of capital return. 
To turn the Printing papers on the next Page, another great quarter in Printing Papers and it was really balance around the world. Printing papers incurred almost half of the total company input cost increases driven by energy and chemicals. We have volumes up in North America and Europe in uncoated free sheet. We're seasonally weak in Russia and Brazil as I mentioned. It's really the weakest quarters they have. And we had stable prices in a slightly negative mix impact. That's kind of a normal occurrence in the first quarter given our customer mix in Brazil. And again, strong operating results in both Europe and Brazil.
Let me turn to Consumer Packaging now. And I thought Consumer Packaging just had an excellent quarter. We benefited from lighter outage quarter but even if you exclude that, still had earnings up 30% in the quarter. And it was really on the strength of all of the businesses, John mentioned the global balance and this is a pretty good example of it. Volumes in North America were up 9%, backlogs continue to be strong, we're still running at 5 plus weeks. Prices were up in all of the regions quarter-on-quarter and if you look at price levels year-on-year, North America is up $92 a ton, our Asia business is up 80 and Europe were up 130 euros per ton in Europe. Operations, again strong and all of the regions including North America where we struggled with mill performance over the past few years. Our Augusta mill finally turn the quarter and we have the first favorable operating results since 2006 in Augusta. So if we concentrated first on North American paperboard. Let me just show you some history in the improvement. If you go back to 2008, we had a 900-basis point improvement through the end of last year and it's really a combination of 3 things. It's restructured commercial contracts and better performance there, its improving operating results in the mills here and it's managing the supply chain better. And now you can see where the margin level in the first quarter run rate of 23%, again it's a light outage quarter but I think the business has positioned itself to be able to achieve margins in the low 20s throughout the year.
Turning to the next page and I'll talk about what I call the other Packaging business. We spent a lot of time talking about Industrial Packaging business but coated paperboard is a global business for us. It's a large business at about 3 million tons globally and North America is a big part of that but it's only part. We also have a very attractive business in Eastern Europe, Russia and we have our Sun joint venture in Asia. You can see the margins for all 3 regions, Asia looks low at 11% but all our earning cost of capital returns in Asia gets there by way of a lower capital base and higher turns. So Asia's turning in our capital at roughly 2x tons versus a little over 1 in North America.
Now let me turn to xpedx where we had a slightly better quarter in the first quarter than in the fourth quarter of last year but we were well behind the first quarter of last year. And really, there's several major factors to that. First of all, paper pricing is increasing and so there's been a little bit of a margin squeeze from that. But we've also seen higher freight and higher fuel cost that hit margins in the first quarter. And then there was a negative LIFO accounting charge in the quarter that we didn't have last year. So all in all, a better quarter in the first quarter but not where we think the business will run on more normalized basis. And as I mentioned on our last quarterly call, the business team has been undergoing a strategic review to dramatically improve earnings and today we have Mary Laschinger, who is the President of xpedx, with us to share some of those plans. So mary, I'll turn it over to you.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tim, good morning, everyone. We're going to use the next few slides to provide an overview of the xpedx profit improvements plan that was mentioned during the fourth quarter earnings call earlier this year. Just a little bit of background. Our Dis
componenttext:
Thanks, Tim, good morning, everyone. We're going to use the next few slides to provide an overview of the xpedx profit improvements plan that was mentioned during the fourth quarter earnings call earlier this year. Just a little bit of background. Our Distribution business in North America is comprised primarily of independent paper and packaging distributors that were acquired by International Paper on the last many years. Prior to the 2009 recession, we were making significant progress in achieving the synergies from all of those acquisitions through increasing our sales revenue and most importantly improving the bottom line, which is shown on Slide 17. And we were showing great progress towards generating cost of capital return. 
Then the recession hit in 2009 and our sales declined by more than 15%. And demand in our primary segment Commercial Print was especially hit hard. And our earnings dropped by about 25%. And so the organization and business went into aggressively reducing operating cost. And you can see, we started to see improvement in 2010 but we're still performing below expectations and what we believe to be our potential. But this reset in the business in 2009 class is to initiate us a strategic review of the business. So over the last 6 months, we've been conducting that strategy review and we confirmed that this business still has significant improvement opportunities. Also as part of the study, we benchmarked other distribution companies as shown in Slide 18, and the data shows that although our asset turns are best in class, our margins lag. We're pleased with our position in terms of against other packaging and paper distributors but our goal is to become 1 of the best among all distributors. 
The external benchmarking and the internal analysis confirmed that we have potential significantly to generate significantly better returns and therefore, our plans are to accelerate the profit improvement plans that we have started prior to the recession. Our strategy for the business remains the same. We're committed to maintaining our position as the largest supplier to the print segment. And we're going to continue to invest in the higher growth segments of packaging and facility solutions. But to support the strategy and to achieve the step change in earnings, we are going to be focusing our change effort around that 3 key drivers in the Distribution business, which are outlined on Slide 19. We believe by focusing on improvements on these key drivers, we can improve our earnings by over $140 million annually. If you look at our distribution business, what we do is we buy products from mills and manufacturers. We handled these products through our network of warehouses and our delivery trucks fleet and we sell these products to a variety of customers. In order for us to achieve significantly better returns we got to be operationally excellent in all 3 of these functions and that's what our goals is. For example in the buy function, we have further opportunity to centralize our procurement processes and decision-making so that we can more effectively leverage our size and scale and most importantly provide a consistent product and service offering to our customers. For example today in our packaging segment, we have about 150 tape suppliers and over 1,200 SKUs. By rationalizing the number of suppliers to a few strategic suppliers and reducing the total number of SKUs, we have the opportunity to improve our asset turns and improve our margins. 
In the handle function, we managed and operate over 100 warehouses across North America. We have further opportunity to optimize our warehouse network and inventory around our customer demand, which will allow us to streamline our operations with fewer, more efficient facility. For example, we recently announced our plan to consolidate 3 facilities in the Salt Lake City area to 1 larger more efficient facility which will be centrally located to support our customer needs. We are also in the process of implementing world-class Warehouse Management System and fleet routing and tracking systems. With all of these initiatives, we have the ability to further reduce our operating cost and improve service to our customers. It is our intent to continue to service all of the geographic markets that we currently serve. 
Finally, in our selling function, we have opportunities to increase productivity in our sales force and invest in additional field marketing capability for the higher growth packaging and facility solutions segment. For us to achieve the $140 million of earnings improvement, we're going to incur about $100 million of net cash cost over about 3-year time period. We're very confident in our ability to implement the plan and improving the earnings and most importantly generate greater than cost of capital return over the next 3 years. So with that, Tim, I'll turn it back to you.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mary. Let me turn to Ilim and talk about what was a great quarter. Again, this is Ilim's fourth quarter, our first quarter because we report on a 1-quarter lag that but volume was up slightly, price was essentially flat on pulp and operations had
componenttext:
Thanks, Mary. Let me turn to Ilim and talk about what was a great quarter. Again, this is Ilim's fourth quarter, our first quarter because we report on a 1-quarter lag that but volume was up slightly, price was essentially flat on pulp and operations had a record quarter. So all in all, Ilim turned in the results we expected and we expect that result to continue to improve as we go into our second quarter, their first. And just to recap for you, we did, John mentioned the dividend we received in the first quarter, that now brings the total dividend received from Ilim over history of the joint venture to write that $200 million on the $650 million investment. So if you look at Ilim's result today, and we recorded on an equity accounting basis but if we were consolidating, Ilim will have the highest return on investment in the company at right at 25% with 30-plus percent EBITDA margins. 
So 1 last slide before I turn it back over to John. And this is really a summary slide. We look at the transformation plan, which happens 3 or 4 years ago but we say that Transformation Plan is really working. And if you go back to 2008, we thought we were on pace to have a cost of capital year in 2009 before the crisis. So as we come through 2010 and recover faster than probably what most expectations were, we positioned ourselves in the second half of last year to have a cost of capital a year in 2011. And in the first quarter, we're in that zone and we see the momentum continuing. So we expect that in 2011, we'll have the year we expected to have in 2009. And with that, I'll turn it back over to John for the outlook.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tim, thanks. I'm going to start the quarter by just repeating what Tim just said. The momentum continues. Despite the input cost headwinds that we got, we got the right businesses in the right places with good discipline and focus execution. And what's th
componenttext: Tim, thanks. I'm going to start the quarter by just repeating what Tim just said. The momentum continues. Despite the input cost headwinds that we got, we got the right businesses in the right places with good discipline and focus execution. And what's that leading is continued strong earnings per share results, free cash flow and ROI. So I'm now on the chart that shows all the red, yellow and green that is really how we think about the outlook going forward. Near-term is more of the same. We're going to get some seasonal volume improvement, that's around the world not just in North America. Some sales pricing improvement, another solid quarter at Ilim. We got 2 significant changes in the second quarter, 1 internal that we managed and that's we're going to the second quarter with a lot of outages that were planned and are heavy outage quarter, that's going to cost us about $0.11 a share, kind of quarter-over-quarter. And we see more input cost headwinds specifically transportation. This means that we had $50 million in the first quarter this year versus the fourth quarter and the second quarter, I don't know how it's going to turn out but it can easily be another $50 million. So with that though, we still expect the second quarter to be solid. We expect good operations, we expect strong cash flow and we expect good solid return on investment across the International Paper portfolio. And with that, I think I'll turn it back to you tom for questions.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Thanks, Tim and Mary. 1 personal note, this will be my final quarterly earnings call as the Head of Investor Relations at IP. I enjoyed working with the investment community over the last 4 years and I appreciate your support. I'm turning th
componenttext: Thanks, John. Thanks, Tim and Mary. 1 personal note, this will be my final quarterly earnings call as the Head of Investor Relations at IP. I enjoyed working with the investment community over the last 4 years and I appreciate your support. I'm turning the IR over to a good friend of mine, Glenn. Glenn has been with IP for more than 20 years. He's working our U.S. and European container businesses. He headed up strategic planning for our forest product business and for the last 4 years, he's been running our containerboard and recycling businesses. I look forward to introducing Glenn to many of you in person. Glenn and I will be available after the Q&A for follow-up questions. With that, I'll turn the call over to Lori for the first question.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Chip Dillon of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Chip Dillon of Credit Suisse.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I had a question actually about Ilim. You mentioned how you pulled almost $200 million out of that investment. Can you just remind us how the footprint of Ilim has changed since you made the investment in '07 and I know that's going to continue into '12 w
componenttext: I had a question actually about Ilim. You mentioned how you pulled almost $200 million out of that investment. Can you just remind us how the footprint of Ilim has changed since you made the investment in '07 and I know that's going to continue into '12 with the pulp expansion. And what their balance sheet changed then?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: The footprint chip hasn't changed a whole lot, it's in the process of changing. We did sell an interest in the bleached board mill that we have that was part of Ilim, but the 3 big assets that we purchased, the uncoated free sheet and containerboard facil
componenttext: The footprint chip hasn't changed a whole lot, it's in the process of changing. We did sell an interest in the bleached board mill that we have that was part of Ilim, but the 3 big assets that we purchased, the uncoated free sheet and containerboard facility in the Northwest and the 2 Siberian pulp mills, there's still in the portfolio. We built a box plant, that's new. And we're rated that's in the first third of the modernization strategy that was part of the whole acquisition that whether there's a project going out of in the Northwest and a paper machine in the quarter and paper machine was relocated from a mill that IP shutdown in Bury in the U.K. and the big pulp modernization and expansion project in Bratsk is underway. So the footprint is in the process of changing. Ilim is funding that capital project through it's own balance sheet and through the free cash generating. So their debt, their balance sheet debt is going up but it's on their balance sheet and it's well within Ilim's financial capability to service that debt.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick follow-up on consumer packaging. It's nice to see the bleached board business coming back to levels like we used to see, back in 80s and 90s. And I noticed the improvement is mostly in the U.S. I saw that Europe did well, is up as we
componenttext: And then just a quick follow-up on consumer packaging. It's nice to see the bleached board business coming back to levels like we used to see, back in 80s and 90s. And I noticed the improvement is mostly in the U.S. I saw that Europe did well, is up as well. But as you look ahead, as you look at the Asian number, which seems to be stuck somewhere in 10 million per quarter range in terms of it's operating income, how could that be improve going forward consistent with what we've seen recently in North America and Europe or is it sort of at its potential right now?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, Katy and who oversees the bleached board business around the world is here. So I'll just let him take that question.
componenttext: Tom, Katy and who oversees the bleached board business around the world is here. So I'll just let him take that question.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our business in China, the JV is essentially sold out so we're cap on through-put. If you look we're selling about 200, somewhat 220,000 tons a quarter I think we were flat year-over-year in terms of output. It's a nonintegrated facility. We have to manag
componenttext: Our business in China, the JV is essentially sold out so we're cap on through-put. If you look we're selling about 200, somewhat 220,000 tons a quarter I think we were flat year-over-year in terms of output. It's a nonintegrated facility. We have to manage our margins there and we did a great job recovering our margins in the first quarter after the runoff in pulp prices hit us in the second half of last year. We had about an 11% ROI on the business in the first quarter. If you look at the first half of last year, I think we were at our high point at about 15% ROI and that's the range that we're going to be in until the new machine starts up, which will be about the fourth quarter of 2012 the next machine.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Skidmore of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Richard Skidmore of Goldman Sachs.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just trying to spend maybe just a minute on Containerboard and how you see your inventories trending through the quarter given the amount of maintenance downtime that you're expecting to take?
componenttext: Just trying to spend maybe just a minute on Containerboard and how you see your inventories trending through the quarter given the amount of maintenance downtime that you're expecting to take?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Carol. Clearly as you can see, we have a very big outage quarter coming in the second quarter and then that will be combined with what we'll see as the seasonal uptick in box demand mainly driven by the seasonality of agriculture of which is
componenttext: Yes, this is Carol. Clearly as you can see, we have a very big outage quarter coming in the second quarter and then that will be combined with what we'll see as the seasonal uptick in box demand mainly driven by the seasonality of agriculture of which is a significant part of our portfolio. So the expectations for us is that our inventories will come down due to that in balance through the quarter. We entered the quarter at about where we need to be. I'm hopeful that the challenge will be for us, if there's an uptick in demand that will create a challenge but that will be fine. We'll manage through that. So that's the phenomenon that we're going to face as we go through the second quarter.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Rick, our inventories are down 30,000 tons in March compared to February and also down compared to the end of last year.
componenttext: Rick, our inventories are down 30,000 tons in March compared to February and also down compared to the end of last year.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just sticking with Containerboard. On Slide 11, you showed the slide where your prices on boxes were $91 Q1 '11 versus Q1 '10. How do you reconcile that with pulp and paper week showed if you look at that you had Pulp & Paper week prices up essentially $1
componenttext: Just sticking with Containerboard. On Slide 11, you showed the slide where your prices on boxes were $91 Q1 '11 versus Q1 '10. How do you reconcile that with pulp and paper week showed if you look at that you had Pulp & Paper week prices up essentially $110 over that time period?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Carol again. That's a great question, what we have to remember these our quarterly averages. And so as you recall, prices were rising through the first quarter of last year so we could average. So if you go from -- if I extract the data on a month
componenttext: This is Carol again. That's a great question, what we have to remember these our quarterly averages. And so as you recall, prices were rising through the first quarter of last year so we could average. So if you go from -- if I extract the data on a monthly basis, the high point from the low point to the high point of box pricing for us was about $107 a ton. So you have to take that into consideration, that's a quarterly average.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Tim. We felt like we got the full increase.
componenttext: This is Tim. We felt like we got the full increase.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, if I might just on the India acquisition. Can you just talk about that business a little bit more and how you see that impacting 2011 and sort of your strategy within India given that recent acquisition?
componenttext: John, if I might just on the India acquisition. Can you just talk about that business a little bit more and how you see that impacting 2011 and sort of your strategy within India given that recent acquisition?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We don't know how's it's going to impact 2011 because we haven't closed on it yet. We don't know when we'll closed, but we expect we will close at some point in time during the year. I'll let Tom Kadien talked to that because he's the one that spent all t
componenttext: We don't know how's it's going to impact 2011 because we haven't closed on it yet. We don't know when we'll closed, but we expect we will close at some point in time during the year. I'll let Tom Kadien talked to that because he's the one that spent all the time in India over the last year getting this to the point where we said we're ready to go.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right now, we're in a 90-day approval period where we have to get approval of both the bank of India and Security Exchange Bureau in India. We expect that will end around the end of June. So we're hopeful to close, we've gotten no indication of any issues
componenttext: Right now, we're in a 90-day approval period where we have to get approval of both the bank of India and Security Exchange Bureau in India. We expect that will end around the end of June. So we're hopeful to close, we've gotten no indication of any issues. So it could close early third quarter. The first phase for us is really to optimize the assets that are on the ground. We think that we can get about 20% productivity improvement out of the existing pulp mill and paper machines that are at the 2 locations. And we think we can do that inside of 2 years with really no capital. After that, what I would call phase 2, 2 years down the road, we'll be looking at expansion projects as we have when we got into other emerging markets. So I think it will be incrementally positive. The business has got good EBITDA margins right now, 23% and we think we can improve on that next year too.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say, we'll talk more about India once we had the business closed. But this looks to us like Ilim look. Very attractive opportunities to build out what's there in a market that's got a lot of growth ahead of both in paper and packaging.
componenttext: I'd say, we'll talk more about India once we had the business closed. But this looks to us like Ilim look. Very attractive opportunities to build out what's there in a market that's got a lot of growth ahead of both in paper and packaging.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham research.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: There are a couple of follow-up questions I did have. 1 is the 140 million, can you give us a sense of timing on when you're hoping to see that improvement flow to the bottom line. And if it's possible perhaps to give us a sense as to, which of the bucket
componenttext: There are a couple of follow-up questions I did have. 1 is the 140 million, can you give us a sense of timing on when you're hoping to see that improvement flow to the bottom line. And if it's possible perhaps to give us a sense as to, which of the buckets would it come from. If it's the buy, the handle, the sell or how you might think about from a kind of bottoms up perspective how to get to the 140? That would be great to the start.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mary Lashinger. First of all, in terms of the timing of the 140, we would begin to see those benefits impact the business as early as next year and would hope to see the full benefit within a 3-year time period. In terms of where those benefits come from,
componenttext: Mary Lashinger. First of all, in terms of the timing of the 140, we would begin to see those benefits impact the business as early as next year and would hope to see the full benefit within a 3-year time period. In terms of where those benefits come from, from the key levers of the business, they're across-the-board on all 3 of those and they're fairly well equally weighted.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just shifting gears. In the Containerboard business, you mentioned you taken about 100,000 tons of market-related downtime, I guess weather-related et cetera. Would have that cost like $25 million or $30 million, so is that a partial offset to the step up
componenttext: Just shifting gears. In the Containerboard business, you mentioned you taken about 100,000 tons of market-related downtime, I guess weather-related et cetera. Would have that cost like $25 million or $30 million, so is that a partial offset to the step up in the maintenance downtime we'll see in the second quarter?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say that your numbers are little high. If you think about it from a non-absorbed fixed cost perspective, it would probably be in, probably $12 million range. And then in addition to that, 1 of the things that we've gotten pretty good at is we actu
componenttext: I would say that your numbers are little high. If you think about it from a non-absorbed fixed cost perspective, it would probably be in, probably $12 million range. And then in addition to that, 1 of the things that we've gotten pretty good at is we actually like our flexibility. Our ability to match our supply and demand where that used to be kind of a big headwind, now we're pretty good. So we optimize the system, optimize low-cost so I do think we have much of a consumption penalty with that downtime.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, since that comes up pretty quickly and we planned outages well ahead of schedule contractors in, we can do a little work but we can't do the outage work when we have market-related downtime. Because we're doing that on-the-fly not planning a head fo
componenttext: Mark, since that comes up pretty quickly and we planned outages well ahead of schedule contractors in, we can do a little work but we can't do the outage work when we have market-related downtime. Because we're doing that on-the-fly not planning a head for it.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I understand that 12 million for the unabsorbed. Presumably though, perhaps you were then you saying the fact that you'll have more tonnage to make profits on you throw that in the seasonality bucket and that will also be a partial offset to the maintenan
componenttext: I understand that 12 million for the unabsorbed. Presumably though, perhaps you were then you saying the fact that you'll have more tonnage to make profits on you throw that in the seasonality bucket and that will also be a partial offset to the maintenance downtime? Is that the way that you're thinking of it? I just want to make sure that I'm not undercounting the kind of offset to the maintenance downtime.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Big offset that we would see for ourselves will be the seasonal uptick in volume. So we will see a stronger second quarter on volume than the first. And that's lever that we've got to offset the increase in cost due to the outages.
componenttext: Big offset that we would see for ourselves will be the seasonal uptick in volume. So we will see a stronger second quarter on volume than the first. And that's lever that we've got to offset the increase in cost due to the outages.

componenttext: And you've got the uncertainty of what input costs were going to do, Mark, that's a bit of long part of this point.

componenttext: But they'll probably head it up. Wild card is how much.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos of the Bank of America-Merrill Lynch.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question I had and maybe piggybacking off with Mark's question, hopefully not too fine a point on this. This juncture given what you can see, would it be unreasonable to expect a sequential drop in 2Q earning versus 1Q or is it too  hard
componenttext: I guess the first question I had and maybe piggybacking off with Mark's question, hopefully not too fine a point on this. This juncture given what you can see, would it be unreasonable to expect a sequential drop in 2Q earning versus 1Q or is it too  hard to call that at this juncture.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: You know we don't give guidance.
componenttext: You know we don't give guidance.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe a question for Carol. Carol, as we think about the Industrial Packaging business and the opportunity that you have to improve returns over the next 2 to 3 years and here I'm thinking mostly about North America. Do you see more opportunity within the
componenttext: Maybe a question for Carol. Carol, as we think about the Industrial Packaging business and the opportunity that you have to improve returns over the next 2 to 3 years and here I'm thinking mostly about North America. Do you see more opportunity within the box business improve returns or do you see it more in the way of mill optimization and further integration there? How should we think about that?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: George, it's a great question and my learning from being in this business for the time I've been in it, it's a large business. And if you want to move the bottom line, you got to have a systemic approach and in my opinion it needs to be a fairly broad-bas
componenttext: George, it's a great question and my learning from being in this business for the time I've been in it, it's a large business. And if you want to move the bottom line, you got to have a systemic approach and in my opinion it needs to be a fairly broad-based approach because 1 thing is not going to move the needle. So we have still opportunity to get better, there's no doubt. We have a very systemic approach on our mills side. We have focused on consumption, fiber energy, chemicals, we have focus on reliability, which then ends up impacting our spending. And we've got capital projects which I referenced in the past relative to some very high returns, targeted, we're talking in this million dollars range, not 50 or 100 by project. Box plant's equally important. And the great part about the box business is you got to play off in sand meaning we need very good competitive facilities and so we're focused there on waste productivity throughput. Bricks and mortar, we closed 3 facilities last fourth quarter because we can get more through the bricks and mortar we have. But simultaneously with that, we got to be focus on our commercial effectiveness. This is a game that you're selling and it's a broad-based selling efforts. So we got a lot of effort there around making sure that we sell value that we priced well, that we do the right things there. And then the other thing we've got the supply chain. 10 million tons across the globe and there's a lot of opportunity to keep getting better and smarter in that and we are making that probably the last piece of our warehouser work, we're putting our operating model in the warehouse or mills right now and that's going to allow us to really make a step change in how we operate that part. All that said, at the end of the day, the key thing that we got to that is low-cost Mills for competitive advantage and manage supply and demand. This business has to be run well from that perspective. And then have a great boxes them to take to market and then as we put in our presentation, leverage our global reach to find the best markets and optimize. So we've got a really great hand to play and I'm convinced we got more opportunity to make it better.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: George, we talked about shifting from integrating the business to optimizing it. As Carol talks about, optimizing a $9 billion business doesn't happen in 12 months. The supply chain capability we're going to have across the mill system as we go into 2012
componenttext: George, we talked about shifting from integrating the business to optimizing it. As Carol talks about, optimizing a $9 billion business doesn't happen in 12 months. The supply chain capability we're going to have across the mill system as we go into 2012 was going to enable really take another chunk of working capital out because we're going to have less rolling stock moving around the system because we're going to have much better visibility and how to schedule mills and get the right rolling stock in the right box plants.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: John, I realized it's a bit of an oversimplification. But given that you're now at cost of capital or higher return within industrial packaging and I'm presuming with the North America, perhaps 1 strategy might be to as you optimize to also perhaps to shr
componenttext: John, I realized it's a bit of an oversimplification. But given that you're now at cost of capital or higher return within industrial packaging and I'm presuming with the North America, perhaps 1 strategy might be to as you optimize to also perhaps to shrink some of your capacity out there in converting or in production, so as to preserve and grow the returns from that avenue. What is in your view wrong with that thinking or what are the opportunities down the road perhaps for that to occur?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: As Carol said we're going to match our supply to demand. We made a major shift footprint when we decided to permanently closed 2 big facilities in Albany, New York and Pineville, Louisiana. Box business is recovering but not fully recovered. We're going t
componenttext: As Carol said we're going to match our supply to demand. We made a major shift footprint when we decided to permanently closed 2 big facilities in Albany, New York and Pineville, Louisiana. Box business is recovering but not fully recovered. We're going to get back to 2000 levels of box consumption and I'm talking about the industry now. Just a question of how many years it's going to take but that's going to happen. So we're not looking at a business that's got a shrinking demand and as Tim pointed out, we have -- our strategy is to serve all 3 markets, the independent market in the U.S., the integrated market and the export market and the global demand for virgin liner boards growing at 3% a year where the U.S. is the low-cost producer and we're the low-cost producer in the U.S. So we're not going to go build another linerboard mill. But we're not looking to shrink the business because we don't see the market shrinking.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Last question, with Augusta, can you remind us what have been some of the issues with that mill in terms of turning around. I think you said you had your first up quarter, I forgot exactly how you phrased it but the comparison was versus 2006, I recall wo
componenttext: Last question, with Augusta, can you remind us what have been some of the issues with that mill in terms of turning around. I think you said you had your first up quarter, I forgot exactly how you phrased it but the comparison was versus 2006, I recall wood fiber being 1 of the factors and so if that was the case, what it take so long to turn the mill back to where you have wanted it to be?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Much more the wood cost, Tom can talk to that.
componenttext: Much more the wood cost, Tom can talk to that.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's really, we under invested in Augusta in a couple of years, going back 5 years and it was more about maintenance and reliability of the whole process from the backend through the machines. And we've just gotten our process back under control. We've in
componenttext: It's really, we under invested in Augusta in a couple of years, going back 5 years and it was more about maintenance and reliability of the whole process from the backend through the machines. And we've just gotten our process back under control. We've invested more than our usual share of maintenance capital over the last 2 years and we work our way from the back end to the machines and have improved reliability. So we're seeing significantly better quality and throughput and we don't have the upsets that we're managing from weekend and month in and out. More on reliability.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two things. John, Mary gave us a pretty clear rundown of what you're doing within distribution to get that back to where you headed before. Can you just walk us and remind us what the strategic benefits of being in that business are. It's been a long road
componenttext: Two things. John, Mary gave us a pretty clear rundown of what you're doing within distribution to get that back to where you headed before. Can you just walk us and remind us what the strategic benefits of being in that business are. It's been a long road obviously, but I think that you guys believe pretty deeply in that business and maybe a little more deeply than some of your investors do.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We do. 80% of what xpedx sells, IP makes. There heavy into the paper merchant channel and there heavy in the packaging. And that's International Paper's core business in North America. And the merchant channel happens to be a big channel for paper compani
componenttext: We do. 80% of what xpedx sells, IP makes. There heavy into the paper merchant channel and there heavy in the packaging. And that's International Paper's core business in North America. And the merchant channel happens to be a big channel for paper companies because a lot of paper gets sold to the merchants. And xpedx happens to be our largest merchant customer but we have a lot of very good and very strategic independent customers. So we don't run the business. On an integrated business, we run it as a standalone profit center and it's a great window to the market for us. Around paper and packaging. If xpedx is in supplies business, we wouldn't be in it because that's not our core business is but paper and packaging is. And we're figuring out ways also to go join the market with xpedx and some of the other IT businesses where we have a capability to do something having distribution and manufacturing that the competition has distribution or just as manufacturing doesn't have. Having said, xpedx has got to earn its cost of capital on its own capital, it's a different kind of business. As Mary said, it's a buy-handle-sell, not a capital-intensive process business. The link, the strategic link is what xpedx sells.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: One more question on container. It seems to me that you not only offset your cost in the quarter but as I look at the cost itself it looks like you managed the input cost a little bit better than some of the competitors did this quarter too. So I'm wonder
componenttext: One more question on container. It seems to me that you not only offset your cost in the quarter but as I look at the cost itself it looks like you managed the input cost a little bit better than some of the competitors did this quarter too. So I'm wondering if Carol, if I could just ask you 1 more time. What specifically were you doing this quarter that you think drove your performance look so much better?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Once again, I would say we had a very good quarter. We did operate well and I think that fact that believe it or not, that we possibly had matching our supply to our demand, we had that downtime. We were able to flex our fiber where we ran and we backed o
componenttext: Once again, I would say we had a very good quarter. We did operate well and I think that fact that believe it or not, that we possibly had matching our supply to our demand, we had that downtime. We were able to flex our fiber where we ran and we backed out some of our highest cost of fiber. But OCC and leverage Virgin, which was good. We continue to see the modest growth, which was helpful. So I think those are some of the things that, we got a great system and 1 of the things that we're building in to our mindset and to our operations is flexibility. And so we have operators by controlled that are focused on how to get gas out of boilers, how to optimally run based upon the demand we got. So I think that's a real competitive advantage we've got. It's a big system, and if you can get your hands around it, you can really leverage it for benefit.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Commercially, Mark, if you look at the results, they speak for themselves 90-plus dollars of price improvement in the box business year-over-year and we're still getting price improvement in the box business through the first quarter. And we're managing b
componenttext: Commercially, Mark, if you look at the results, they speak for themselves 90-plus dollars of price improvement in the box business year-over-year and we're still getting price improvement in the box business through the first quarter. And we're managing business very well in the commercial side.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman of UBS.

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could talk about a little bit underlying demand trends and help us see through some of these seasonal noise that happen in the first quarter and what you're seeing kind of early in the second quarter?
componenttext: I wonder if you could talk about a little bit underlying demand trends and help us see through some of these seasonal noise that happen in the first quarter and what you're seeing kind of early in the second quarter?

headline: International Paper Co., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we're seeing what we would expect, Gail. Seasonal improvement in the U.S. in the face of GDP number just came up 1.8%. March feels a whole lot better than January and February for obvious reasons. And April feeling like it's usual kind of a April
componenttext: I think we're seeing what we would expect, Gail. Seasonal improvement in the U.S. in the face of GDP number just came up 1.8%. March feels a whole lot better than January and February for obvious reasons. And April feeling like it's usual kind of a April and call it at 2% GDP environment. So we're feeling pretty positive about the demand in the U.S. but not before. On the paper side the underlying structure issues have been changed. We just got a recovering economy. I think March was the first month that we had fairly strong paper shipments. So even if we get a couple of months of positive year-over-year paper shipments we still think the underlying demand trends are slightly down, we have to see how that plays out. Around the world, it's a different story. Brazil, paper shipments were up 7% quarter-over-quarter. Our box business including Turkey, which we do equity accounting just state the volume for a box business and Europe was up 11% quarter-over-quarter. So those kinds of numbers are indicative of the fact that the world outside North America is growing at pretty healthy rates and we're in those markets. And that's kind of 1 of the IP differences. So the bleached board business, looks quite that business came back faster than Containerboard in terms on the demand side it fell very sharply in the first quarter last year that was a low watermark but we're back to sold out with strong backlogs. It feels like we're recovering but not a fully recovered economy in North America and outside North America, it feels like the rest of the world, even places like Europe that we think we really have problems are showing some pretty good growth for us especially in packaging.
