headline: International Paper Co., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess 2-part question, if I could. Two different questions, if I could. First, I'm curious, John, how you think about whether there's an opportunity cost related to the deal dragging on over time? And I'm really thinking about the type of response and b
componenttext: I guess 2-part question, if I could. Two different questions, if I could. First, I'm curious, John, how you think about whether there's an opportunity cost related to the deal dragging on over time? And I'm really thinking about the type of response and behavior that Willamette had in reaction to the Weyerhaeuser bid over the 2-year period, and whether or not you view this as something that could be disruptive, which potentially has a true cost to your business? So how do you think about the opportunity cost of a deal that could drag on?

headline: International Paper Co., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of our business performance, Pete, I don't see any opportunity cost. We're focused on running International Paper as it is all across the company, as I said from Memphis to Shanghai to So Paulo, to Bratsk in Russia. In terms of time frame
componenttext: Well, in terms of our business performance, Pete, I don't see any opportunity cost. We're focused on running International Paper as it is all across the company, as I said from Memphis to Shanghai to So Paulo, to Bratsk in Russia. In terms of time frame, I think there's an opportunity cost to Temple shareowners. We've made a serious offer that's 20% above their all-time high, and we think the right thing to do is to sit down with Temple and have a serious discussion. The world moves on and we're committed, we're serious, we're patient, we're disciplined. If things change at some point in time, and we think the right thing for International Paper is to do something else, we'll make that call. But we're serious and we're committed to this and we'll be disciplined.

headline: International Paper Co., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, John, as we all try to figure out the next steps here, what appears at the moment to be a standoff. One point that I'm not clear on, is it even possible for Temple to have a confidential conversation with you at this point or doesn't the hostil
componenttext: Okay. And, John, as we all try to figure out the next steps here, what appears at the moment to be a standoff. One point that I'm not clear on, is it even possible for Temple to have a confidential conversation with you at this point or doesn't the hostile nature of the deal at this point preempt that from happening?

componenttext: Well, now that we've launched a tender offer, there are some things we have to comply with. And I guess Id just leave it right there. We've got plenty of advisors, at least International Paper does. I presume Temple does. And there's always a way to have a discussion if we choose to have one. But I'm not going to get into what we have to do under any circumstance.

headline: International Paper Co., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe just lastly, on the tender itself with the date coming up, shares of Temple trading roughly at the bid. Can you remind us on the flexibility you have with that tender? I guess, you'll cross the bridge when you get to it. But can you extend tha
componenttext: Okay. Maybe just lastly, on the tender itself with the date coming up, shares of Temple trading roughly at the bid. Can you remind us on the flexibility you have with that tender? I guess, you'll cross the bridge when you get to it. But can you extend that tender offer in an effort to try to facilitate a higher participation rate?

headline: International Paper Co., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, we can extend it a number of times. We've launched a tender process because we weren't having meaningful discussions, we're serious and we wanted to get the kind of the train rolling. So that's where we are but we can extend the tender offer and exp
componenttext:
Sure, we can extend it a number of times. We've launched a tender process because we weren't having meaningful discussions, we're serious and we wanted to get the kind of the train rolling. So that's where we are but we can extend the tender offer and expect that we will do that. 
Okay, operator, I think that wraps it up. So thank you very much for tuning in. We're pretty pleased with the quarter and look forward to talking to you on the next quarter.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Laurie, and good morning, and thank you for joining International Paper's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are John Farci, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Nicholls, Senior Vice President and Chief
componenttext: Thanks, Laurie, and good morning, and thank you for joining International Paper's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are John Farci, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Tim Nicholls, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. During this call, as always, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties which are outlined in Slide 2 of our presentation. We will also present certain non-US GAAP financial information and the reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures will be available in our website. Our website also contains copies of the third quarter 2011 earnings press release and today's presentation slides to follow. I will now turn the call over to John Faraci.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Glenn, and good morning, everybody. Let me just start by saying we're pretty pleased, very pleased with our third quarter results. I think the $0.92 a share reflects the global balance of International Paper. Our focused businesses continue to pro
componenttext:
Thanks, Glenn, and good morning, everybody. Let me just start by saying we're pretty pleased, very pleased with our third quarter results. I think the $0.92 a share reflects the global balance of International Paper. Our focused businesses continue to produce strong earnings and free cash flow. Basically, it was a study volumes and a weak economic environment, stable pricing, outstanding operations, very strong contributions from our joint venture in Russia. We also set input cost escalation and achieved cost of capital returns. And if you think about our earnings, they are substantially up from the second quarter. And adjusting the third quarter 2010 for a land sale, they were up 11% relative to the third quarter last year. This next chart here shows the balance in the global portfolio. We had strong contributions from both our Paper and Packaging businesses, as you can see. 30% of our operating earnings are coming from the platforms we have had outside North America that have a lot of volume revenue and earnings growth. 
EBITDA margins roved improved across all our global manufacturing businesses, up strongly 300 basis points from where they were in 2010. And again, that just sets the stage for I think underscores International Paper's ability to perform in a challenging economic environment. So with that is just a brief introduction. I'll turn it over to Tim to go through the business

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, and thanks, John. Good morning, everyone. I'm on Slide 7, and I want to just start off by saying that we had, as John said, really strong results in the quarter and what's been a difficult environment. The third quarter of last year has been adjuste
componenttext:
Okay, and thanks, John. Good morning, everyone. I'm on Slide 7, and I want to just start off by saying that we had, as John said, really strong results in the quarter and what's been a difficult environment. The third quarter of last year has been adjusted for the landscape. You can see revenues up nearly 2% versus same time last year. The margins continued to remain very solid and cash has been strong, up from the second quarter and very close to the third quarter last year, even with $130 million more in capital investment in the third quarter of this year than last year. Cash balance grew from the end of last quarter this quarter by another $300 million. If you look at the second quarter versus third quarter earnings performance, a strong quarter in a tough environment, price and volume basically flat despite the weak backdrop. Volume was weaker earlier in the quarter and then showed some improvement as we move towards the end of the quarter. Operations continued to improve after a very strong performance in the second quarter. So the facilities are running extremely well at the moment. We did have a lighter maintenance outage schedule but we executed it extremely well. And the tax rate was slightly lower because of a couple of discrete items in the quarter that won't repeat in the fourth quarter. 
Just turning to our year-over-year performance, and I think this is a real story of improvement. If you take out the land sales from last year, $0.83 versus the $0.92 that John mentioned, price offset the softer volume, and really, as I mentioned on the operations, operations and cost management have completely offset the higher input costs that we faced year-over-year. Lower interest and taxes, along with another quarter of really strong results from Ilim added headroom. 
If you look at the next slide, I think what's even more impressive for the year-to-date results from continuing operations, a top line growth of 7%, EBIT growth up 56%, a doubling of EPS and a 50% improvement in cash provided by operations. And if you look at the cash balancing, again these numbers from last year have been adjusted for land sales about $1.2 billion in cash last year and up to 2.7, this year, 125% improvement. Of course, the building of cash in part because we are looking to bring cash to the Temple close. 
So all of that, what is meant is 5 quarters now of really strong improvement in terms of earnings, starting in the third quarter of last year. And we've put together 5 quarters that are really in the cost of capital zone and feel good about where we are as we go into the fourth quarter and 2012. 
So now, let me turn back to the quarter itself. Input costs, the increases have moderated. In most categories, we did see the exception in OCC during the quarter but in most other categories, chemicals energies, we saw smaller increases than we've seen in previous quarters and that was not only here in North America but in other parts of the world. But because of the OCC, nearly 2/3 of the increase in the quarter was felt in industrial packaging. 
So now, I'll turn to the segments and start with industrial packaging. Even with that increase posted another strong quarter with EBIT moving from 269 to 301 in the quarter. North American prices were relatively stable in the quarter. We did see a little bit of erosion in export Containerboard. Volume was down slightly, and I think it is a slight decrease and it is roughly split half in North America where we saw a slight decrease in box shipments and a slight decrease in domestic Containerboard shipments. And the other half was in Europe where the third quarter is seasonally a weaker quarter in Europe. we've seen a little bit of softness in the industrial segment, but fruit and vegetable continues to perform well. 
The third quarter's earnings were favorably impacted by the lower mill outage scheduled. But as I mentioned, we executed that very well and it was also impacted by the avoidance of the Vicksburg charge that we had in the second quarter although I would say that there are still some smaller residuals as supply-chain cost impacts as we try to recover from that downtime and get product back in the right places. And then as I mentioned, the OCC costs were up and that was about $14 million of the negative impact in input cost. So another quarter. IPG posted the highest margin in the industry again this quarter and it for the entire year as well as 8 out of the last 11 quarters. On a sequential basis, quarter-on-quarter, we added 200 basis points by executing well and taking advantage of the lighter maintenance schedule. And the spread between competition in the quarter was 280 basis points. That's the largest we've had in over 2 years. 
Turning to consumer. Consumer packaging had another very good quarter, a string of quarters that they're putting together now. On a steady volume, improved price realizations associated with the pass-through of previous announcements. Our operational performance was down slightly in the quarter but again off of a very strong second quarter so they continue to perform at the very high level. And this business also benefited from the lighter maintenance outage schedule. 
If you turn to the slides, to the next one , just to highlight where some of these operating performance is coming from, it's really being driven in significant part by outstanding manufacturing and supply-chain performance. You can see that this year, we've generated $30 million of cash cost savings. That's roughly $20 a ton in the manufacturing operations and it's coming from improved reliability and energy usage, a better uptime availability, and basically, just running a more consistent manufacturing operation. The supply chain improvement are really -- all the metrics are moving in the right direction, and as you can see on slide. And the result is we're generating nearly $1 million a month of savings. So the business is operating very well, the key levers in control. What that resulted in is business results that are continuing to be strong and consistent and in the cost of capital zone now for the last 5 quarters, And year-to-date the business has earned 75% more in the first 3 quarters of this year than in all of 2012. 
Additionally, Coated Paperboard. Our North American Coated Paperboard business is realizing the benefits on the commercial side from our Foodservice business. It's not the business that we highlight very often but just sharing some history here. If you look at the next slide, Foodservice basically makes paper cups and food containers. And the business source is roughly 100% of its board from the North American business. We saw a significant decrease in demand during the economic crisis, but this year, the business is on pace to return to prerecession volume levels. And it's doing it, really, on innovative products like the ecotainer and the Hold&Go hot beverage cup. So with those products, margins are up. Year-to-date, margins are up 250 basis points from the low of 2008, it's up 60 basis points year-over-year, and now higher than what we had before the economic crisis. 
Printing papers, a great quarter. We had exceptionally good quarter in North America. Our operations in Europe were basically flat quarter-on-quarter. Brazil was roughly flat quarter-on-quarter, mostly because of seasonality and how the seasons slow in those 2 businesses. North America really lifted results by posting strong manufacturing operations. 
Now turning to xpedx. And while the year-over-year revenue is down, clearly, we saw xpedx bounced back in the quarter, nearly doubling its earnings on a seasonal demand lift and good volumes around printing and packaging quarter-on-quarter. 
And if you look at the next slide, you'll see really we are getting some help from the market but we're also seeing the beginnings of the benefits from the strategy implementation that Mary took you through a quarter or so ago. Average daily in shipping rates on printing paper were up 8% on strong seasonal rebound in the publishing grades. We've also been managing our costs effectively and have good realization of estimate cost and headcount reductions with headcount being down 7% year-to-date. So we think the strategy is starting to take hold. And as we promised, Mary will be back at the end of the fourth quarter to update you on the strategy and how the implementation is going. 
Now turning to Ilim. Another strong quarter from the Ilim joint venture. And just as a reminder, it's their second quarter, our third quarter as we continue to report on the lag. So in their second quarter, prices were higher for both pulp and Containerboard. We did see lower volumes and we had higher outage costs than input costs in the quarter. We did receive another dividend in the quarter. It's our second dividend from the joint venture this year and it brings our total cumulative dividends to $234 million since the beginnings of the joint venture. So we've roughly recovered a little bit more than 1/3 of the original investment through dividends. One item that I would note about what will be our fourth quarter, the joint venture's third quarter, we did see a significant weakening in the quarter of the ruble. And because the joint venture has dollar denominated debt, it had to mark that to market. So we will see about a $50 million charge in their third quarter, our fourth quarter reported. It's a non-cash charge and we really like the movement in the ruble as it weakens because it makes the business more competitive and enhances margins over time. 
Just an update on capital expansion. A couple of pictures here. One from the Bratsk mill where we are putting in the new pulp line and see the digester coming out of the ground there. And right now, we are still on track for a start up in 2012. Again, as a reminder, this is about a $700 million project and its projected return at about 20%. The other picture you see is from the mill and it's for uncoated freesheet capacity. Although, we will also have an opportunity to become the first producer of Coated Paper in Russia by putting, installing a coder at the end of the line. This also is scheduled for 2012 start up. And again, nearly $300 million in capital being invested with the greater than 20% return. So we've talked about this for a few quarters now. I thought it would be interesting for people to seek that their structure coming out of the ground at this point. 
So just summarizing our third quarter, I think John covered this is at the beginning but we do feel very good about a very strong quarter in the third quarter. The global balance is paying off and will continue to pay off as we go through the balance of this year and into next year. Volumes pricing steady. We continued to operate our facilities extremely well and manage costs tightly. The strong contribution from Illm the I mentioned will decrease in the fourth quarter because of the non-cash currency charge. But in terms of their operating performance, they continued to operate very well. So again, 5 quarters now in the cost of capital zone and feel good about where we are even though our inputs are up, we are managing so far to offset them in the cost management and operating capabilities. 
And if you look at the last slide, just showing you ROI. So far year-to-date we are at 8%. In the quarter, we are actually over 9%. So we feel very good about posting a cost of capital results for 2011. With that, I'll turn it back over to John for the outlook.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. I'm on Page 26 for those of you who are following along with the slides. The fourth quarter outlook. What this says, as we look at it is volume is going to be seasonally slower. It always is as we get into the fourth quarter. We've got more m
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. I'm on Page 26 for those of you who are following along with the slides. The fourth quarter outlook. What this says, as we look at it is volume is going to be seasonally slower. It always is as we get into the fourth quarter. We've got more maintenance outages. More the same in terms of the overall economic environment. Pricing looks to be stable with the exception of lower pulp prices which have been occurring over the last several quarters. As Jim said, we have the currency hit, $55 million, 12% weakening of ruble. We are also going to start incur some start up costs as we get ready to complete the project and frankly, Virginia convert that bill into a pulp line. But I think, more importantly, looking beyond the normal seasonal slowdown in the fourth quarter, I'm quite very positive that International Paper going into 2012 for a number of reasons. We've got India which Tom Kadien we'll talk about in a minute. That's coming online. We've got major investments in Russia that Tim talked about it remember those are being financed off the Ilim balance sheet, not by International Paper but by the joint venture that will begin to contribute to results towards the end of next year. And we've got the importantly, Temple coming later this year come early next year which will significantly country be to our ability to further take costs out of our important North American Industrial Packaging business. So all in, well, the fourth quarter is going to be the usual kind of fourth quarter and the economic environment is more or less the same. We're very positive that International Paper as we end this year and go into next year. Tom Kadien, do you want to give an update in India?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure, John, thanks. We closed on our transaction in the and we are now owner of 75% of the shares of Paper Company. We had day 1 activities with employees at both mills, with government officials, with over 200 of the 3 farmers that supply fiber to the mi
componenttext: Sure, John, thanks. We closed on our transaction in the and we are now owner of 75% of the shares of Paper Company. We had day 1 activities with employees at both mills, with government officials, with over 200 of the 3 farmers that supply fiber to the mill and reactions have been really good thus far. We're in the process of establishing governance over the company. We have a team of IP folks on the ground in Hyderabad since July, really. led by Paul Brown, who was one of our most experienced global executives. We have integration plans that are in at fulltilt right now, in finance, in capital buildout plans, manufacturing excellence as well as IP, forestry, environment health and safety and compliance. And their most recent quarter, or last quarter, APPM had a good quarter. Revenue is growing 10%. And as we look forward to '12, we think we're looking for double-digit increases in tons, earnings, and we feel like we have a lot of runway in front of us. Some of you have asked Glenn about the dispute, I guess, over the noncompete fee, and $25 million that's held in escrow right now. There is a date set of November 16 with the securities what will make that decision. And again, our advisors think that we are on strong ground and it will go in our favor. That said, in India, nothing happens quite as scheduled. So we're hoping it comes off on November 60. And then I guess the last thing, we're still evaluating when we're going to report out on results and how we can sync that out. And you'll hear more about that on future calls.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Tom. Let me just give you a quick update on where we are with Temple. We continued to move forward to our closing date. We think that's likely to be towards the end of the year or early in 2012. 2 remained regulatory approval and a Final vot
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Tom. Let me just give you a quick update on where we are with Temple. We continued to move forward to our closing date. We think that's likely to be towards the end of the year or early in 2012. 2 remained regulatory approval and a Final vote by Temple shareowners. They will filed the proxy based on the comments they get back from the initial filing. Our Internal Integration Steering Committee working on post closing plans. And with the leadership and management of this integration are an experienced and capable bunch of IT people. They know what to do and we are getting good cooperation from Temple. So this chart just shows you on the top of the regulatory timeframe, and on the bottom the merger timeframe. 
Before we open up to your questions, I just like to make couple of comments on the we announced this week. We have a very strong and capable management team at International Paper. And I think our results over the last several years, going through the Transformation Plan, coming out of it, managing through the downturn and now a slower recovery demonstrates that. These moves are really the result of a lot of discussion, a lot of thoughts on my part and making them now get us ready for 2012 and beyond. So I've got absolute confidence that going forward, what you're going to see from International Paper is IP style execution and IP style results. So with that, why don't we open up for questions?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, John. Operator, please begin the question-and-answer session.
componenttext: Okay, John. Operator, please begin the question-and-answer session.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman of UBS.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was a little curious about the comments about demand actually getting stronger towards the end of the quarter. That's a little bit in contrast what we've heard from some other companies. I'm just wondering if you could give a little bit more color on th
componenttext: I was a little curious about the comments about demand actually getting stronger towards the end of the quarter. That's a little bit in contrast what we've heard from some other companies. I'm just wondering if you could give a little bit more color on the demand environment? And also maybe specifically, touch on the exports on the container board front?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I guess strong, it's all around the expectations of what you're expecting them to be. And so I think what I would say is boxed demand continues to move sideways. And relative to some of the headlines and the bad news you read, that's actually pretty g
componenttext: And I guess strong, it's all around the expectations of what you're expecting them to be. And so I think what I would say is boxed demand continues to move sideways. And relative to some of the headlines and the bad news you read, that's actually pretty good news. So I feel like boxed demand is pretty stable and that continued really through the quarter and into October for us.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: How is October looking?
componenttext: How is October looking?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: October is looking okay relative -- well, we're almost done with the month, compared to last year, it's looking reasonable. And sequentially, from September, it's down slightly but you would expect that seasonally. So October box demand is continuing to h
componenttext: October is looking okay relative -- well, we're almost done with the month, compared to last year, it's looking reasonable. And sequentially, from September, it's down slightly but you would expect that seasonally. So October box demand is continuing to hold and I feel pretty good about that. Relative to exports, the export market has got a combination of 2 things going on. In the export market, there has been some slowdown in boxed demand in these markets. That's combined with the piper exports, kind of along pipe. So takes place 2 or 3 months for them to get there. So that, combined with extra supply that those markets, has called a little deterioration in pricing but I think that's just a temporary supply chain activity and I don't see any real decline in demand in the export markets through time.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, would you make a comment on print papers?
componenttext: Mark, would you make a comment on print papers?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd be happy to. So for North American printing papers, in the third quarter, we saw demand relatively stable. The published data says the markets down a little over 3% year-over-year. But the combination of some capacity shuts and some temporary int
componenttext: Yes, I'd be happy to. So for North American printing papers, in the third quarter, we saw demand relatively stable. The published data says the markets down a little over 3% year-over-year. But the combination of some capacity shuts and some temporary interruption has occurred early in the year, with exports up and imports down, it's been pretty well balanced.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess Gail, overall, we don't see things definitely in the second half of the year got weaker relative to the first half, from a macro standpoit, that showed up in our businesses. But from here, it just seems like more the same.
componenttext: I guess Gail, overall, we don't see things definitely in the second half of the year got weaker relative to the first half, from a macro standpoit, that showed up in our businesses. But from here, it just seems like more the same.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, can you talk a little bit about on pricing? There's been an awful lot of noise in some of the trade press, and it doesn't seem to be showing up in your numbers and I'm just wondering if you're experiencing any of the weaknesses that's being reported
componenttext: Mark, can you talk a little bit about on pricing? There's been an awful lot of noise in some of the trade press, and it doesn't seem to be showing up in your numbers and I'm just wondering if you're experiencing any of the weaknesses that's being reported?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have seen a pretty stable pricing environment. Pricing announcements went out earlier in the year and depending on the grade, the channel and the customer, there's all kinds of different realizations schedules. But we've seen pretty stable pricing
componenttext: Yes. We have seen a pretty stable pricing environment. Pricing announcements went out earlier in the year and depending on the grade, the channel and the customer, there's all kinds of different realizations schedules. But we've seen pretty stable pricing on the paper side.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last question. Can you talk a little bit about net interest expense? You continued to be guided towards the pickup and it's not showing through. Has there been something unusual going on this year? Is there any real reason to think it's
componenttext: Okay. And just one last question. Can you talk a little bit about net interest expense? You continued to be guided towards the pickup and it's not showing through. Has there been something unusual going on this year? Is there any real reason to think it's going to pick up? And maybe also can you give an update on potential financing cost related with associated with the Temple deal?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We've talked about it for a couple of quarters now. It moves around. But with 10-year looks like it's roughly 5% to 3 to 5.5% and 30 years probably going to be 6.7%, 6.8% to 7% but it's so volatile right now, it's changing day-to-day. And we have seen bas
componenttext: We've talked about it for a couple of quarters now. It moves around. But with 10-year looks like it's roughly 5% to 3 to 5.5% and 30 years probably going to be 6.7%, 6.8% to 7% but it's so volatile right now, it's changing day-to-day. And we have seen base rates move up a little bit of course and the credit spreads tightening little bit. So on interest expense, we did benefit a little bit. We were able to put some swaps on and we saw a little bit of benefit from our floating debt. But you've seen 3 quarters now. I don't expect it to be dramatically different in the fourth.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connolly of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connolly of CLSA.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just 2 things. Ilim has actually been in the news quite a bit lately over in Russia and recently they've been highlighting their container board performance. You've talked about Russia as an attractive place to potentially expand container board, too. I'm
componenttext: Just 2 things. Ilim has actually been in the news quite a bit lately over in Russia and recently they've been highlighting their container board performance. You've talked about Russia as an attractive place to potentially expand container board, too. I'm curious if that's still your opinion? That's the first question. And second question, is there anything changing in your outlook for capital spending x Temple as you start thinking about 2012 in this new economic environment?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we like container board in Russia. In Siberia, we're going to make less container board make more pulp. That's what the projects expansion is all about. Container board in the Russian packaging market is growing. So that's a business that you will s
componenttext: Well, we like container board in Russia. In Siberia, we're going to make less container board make more pulp. That's what the projects expansion is all about. Container board in the Russian packaging market is growing. So that's a business that you will see us continue to try to take advantage of, our low cost position in Russia. On the capital side, I think we've outlined what our capital spending plants over the sides will be about $1 billion a year. We've been well under that for a couple of years. We're likely to be able to cover that as we go into 2012 because we've got paper machine in China that we're building. But roughly over the 5-year period you talk about a couple of years ago, our capital spending at the end of the day will still be at $1 billion a year. It'll be a little bit over that next year.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you're not pulling back any of your spending plans at this point given economics?
componenttext: Okay. So you're not pulling back any of your spending plans at this point given economics?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. in our spending plans, we're generating a lot of cash, our spending plans in North America taking cost out of the system and very selectively around the world. We're adding capacity, or modernizing capacity where markets are growing, generating a lot
componenttext: No. in our spending plans, we're generating a lot of cash, our spending plans in North America taking cost out of the system and very selectively around the world. We're adding capacity, or modernizing capacity where markets are growing, generating a lot of cash and we are going to use it to use away.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steven Atkinson of Bank of Montral.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: First of all, really wanted to thank Tim for all his time spent. It was much appreciated. In terms of the -- what I was looking at, in terms of China where I'm reading a slowdown and so on, can you talk about where you're at in terms of your bleach board
componenttext: First of all, really wanted to thank Tim for all his time spent. It was much appreciated. In terms of the -- what I was looking at, in terms of China where I'm reading a slowdown and so on, can you talk about where you're at in terms of your bleach board business and your box converting business?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Tom, do you want to comment in China?
componenttext: Tom, do you want to comment in China?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. Steve, we have seen a slowdown in China, from 10% growth to 9% growth or 8% growth. The box business has slowed down but we still, we are growing our box business, I think in the third quarter we were up 4% or 5% on volume year-over-year. And there'
componenttext: Sure. Steve, we have seen a slowdown in China, from 10% growth to 9% growth or 8% growth. The box business has slowed down but we still, we are growing our box business, I think in the third quarter we were up 4% or 5% on volume year-over-year. And there's a lot of price on that year-over-year as well. And in our joint venture with on Coated Paperboard, we really haven't seen a slowdown manifest itself in volumes at all. There is some pricing pressure because of the pulp prices that are coming down in the market. We're now integrated and that kind of rattles around the market. But we remain fully sold-out on the code of board decide. and We are actually having a very good year. Have cost of capital returns so far year-to-date. Our new machine were under construction, as John said, and we expect to start that up in the fourth quarter next year.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's interesting, people talk about slowdown in China. It is slowing but 8% growth on a $5 trillion economy is the same as 10% growth on a $4 trillion economy. So I think we need to remember that the Chinese economy has been growing at the very large rate
componenttext: It's interesting, people talk about slowdown in China. It is slowing but 8% growth on a $5 trillion economy is the same as 10% growth on a $4 trillion economy. So I think we need to remember that the Chinese economy has been growing at the very large rate. The economy is growing bigger so the aggregate growth in GDP still significant which is what we're seeing.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in terms of India, I know you're just starting. Are you able to talk about the paper business in India?
componenttext: And in terms of India, I know you're just starting. Are you able to talk about the paper business in India?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. The under production  -- is an uncoated free sheet company, on the slide, you see the Russia mill is integrated and then the other mill, the coastal mill, as and recycled papers. The market over there has been growing 10% to 15%, probably cutsized,
componenttext: Sure. The under production  -- is an uncoated free sheet company, on the slide, you see the Russia mill is integrated and then the other mill, the coastal mill, as and recycled papers. The market over there has been growing 10% to 15%, probably cutsized, it's growing at 15% a year. We think that we can continue to grow with that market. It's a huge country, 1.2 billion people. The government is committed to educating folks and a lot of them don't have access to electricity. So we think the uncoated free sheet future is very good over there and we've got a good position way of the 4 Street program in the state of Andhra Pradesh for most of the fiber in the country lies. so we're pretty bullish about that but it's also we're 2 weeks into this, so we have a lot of work to go. But it's a great market. Think with a strong future.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: If you look at India from a paper packaging standpoint, it's probably where China was 10 to 15 years ago. And one the really interesting things about Andhra Pradesh is India, like China, is going to be a net fiber importer, probably for as far as we can s
componenttext: If you look at India from a paper packaging standpoint, it's probably where China was 10 to 15 years ago. And one the really interesting things about Andhra Pradesh is India, like China, is going to be a net fiber importer, probably for as far as we can see. But Andhra Pradesh paper is not the only but one of the few successful farm for street programs which gives us the real advantage over import of pulp. And as we build out that programs, we'll be able to take advantage of that.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So I expect in the near term, you are going to optimize 60 productions and that's why are able to get a double-digit growth in production? And then down the road, work on, shall we say, the integration?
componenttext: So I expect in the near term, you are going to optimize 60 productions and that's why are able to get a double-digit growth in production? And then down the road, work on, shall we say, the integration?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's right. The markets growing double digits. So we certainly think we can optimize the existing manufacturing operations. There's a lot of handled folks over there but they're not quite sure what excellence looks like in manufacturing and we're p
componenttext: Yes, that's right. The markets growing double digits. So we certainly think we can optimize the existing manufacturing operations. There's a lot of handled folks over there but they're not quite sure what excellence looks like in manufacturing and we're pretty confident we can show them.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions here. First, you mentioned that the Mills and certainly the operating performance was better than we were forecasting. Congratulations on that. You are taking more maintenance downtime in this quarter. I don't have a beat on that yet
componenttext: A couple of questions here. First, you mentioned that the Mills and certainly the operating performance was better than we were forecasting. Congratulations on that. You are taking more maintenance downtime in this quarter. I don't have a beat on that yet but so far how is progressing? Any on pressing issues or are things progressing fairly smoothly there?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say overall execution continues to be very good and international papers got over 30 mills around the world. And we intensely plan for these outages. We track the cost, the time we're down, the work to get completed and the ramp-up. and we spend close
componenttext: I'd say overall execution continues to be very good and international papers got over 30 mills around the world. And we intensely plan for these outages. We track the cost, the time we're down, the work to get completed and the ramp-up. and we spend close $400 million in maintenance outages a year. So a 10% shortfall, a 10% improvement on getting to work done in the time and at the cost level makes a big difference.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And, John, aside from the planning and maybe this isn't the reason but what do you think IP does differently than other companies, if anything at all, in terms of planning for in a maintenance outages?
componenttext: And, John, aside from the planning and maybe this isn't the reason but what do you think IP does differently than other companies, if anything at all, in terms of planning for in a maintenance outages?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We invest in technologies, engineering, improved organization. And as with bought some other paper and packaging companies and IP, most of them have what we call it a run organization. They have people that run the mills and they do that very well to the
componenttext: We invest in technologies, engineering, improved organization. And as with bought some other paper and packaging companies and IP, most of them have what we call it a run organization. They have people that run the mills and they do that very well to the best of their abilities. We also think it makes sense to spend some money and we will make more money by having resources that really go around the world where the summer in India right now and already helping. on their paper that are early subject matter experts and work on the improved side of the business as well as the run side. So when you put those 2 together, the capability to run very well but also an experienced and people that can plan for improvement, I think you get the best of both worlds and something that International Paper, frankly, does better than a lot, if not all, of our competitors, because we invest in it.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Two last questions. Again, the on same theme, you done a wonderful job over the last number of years of improving performance in uncoated free sheet and the Printing Papers segment overall. You obviously demand has been a headwind at times. We've talked a
componenttext: Two last questions. Again, the on same theme, you done a wonderful job over the last number of years of improving performance in uncoated free sheet and the Printing Papers segment overall. You obviously demand has been a headwind at times. We've talked about that in our research. Do you feel that if you have to manage the manufacturing footprint yet again at some point in the next few years, that paper machine or mill might be the straw that alters the camels back and perhaps leads to a lower profit per ton on a going forward basis, because whatever logistical or other issue that could arise from that? Or do you feel comfortable about being able to manage the capacity and at the same time, managing the profitability trend where it is right now?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. That's a tough question to answer, obviously because you really are speculating about what you might do in the future. But I think at the high-level, we found the way to change our footprint in the past where in some cases, cost temporarily
componenttext: This is Mark. That's a tough question to answer, obviously because you really are speculating about what you might do in the future. But I think at the high-level, we found the way to change our footprint in the past where in some cases, cost temporarily go up. Using our supply chain tools and some other operating tactic, we've been able to mitigate a lot of that. And if you look at probably do that again. Our mills our where they are and our customers are were they are and there's not a dramatic geographic change that would happen if we have to take additional capacity out.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Last question. On the Mills -- or let me backup. In container board in North America, in particular, where do you feel you have opportunities to improve returns from here? On the Mills side and on the converting side?
componenttext: Last question. On the Mills -- or let me backup. In container board in North America, in particular, where do you feel you have opportunities to improve returns from here? On the Mills side and on the converting side?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Carol. I think there's opportunity in both sides of that business and the mills, the key to getting to superior results is you have to have a low cost for a competitive advantage. Meaning you can't just be low cost but you have to be lower so we c
componenttext: This is Carol. I think there's opportunity in both sides of that business and the mills, the key to getting to superior results is you have to have a low cost for a competitive advantage. Meaning you can't just be low cost but you have to be lower so we continually work. And the great news for us is we've got a good fleet of mill with options to make it better. In a very hopeful testable we will have even more opportunities there. That said, we sell boxes and the box business is very important. And the box business, you've to be good. My sports analogy is both sides of the ball. You've to have low-cost, box plants that do whatever they're going to do well. And so the call that competitive and profitable box. So you've got to have the facilities that do the job well effectively, better than to come position but at the same time you have to spell it respectively. And that means you're getting paid for the value you bring. So we believe there's opportunity on both sides and clearly we're excited after Temple inland we will have more opportunity to drive more cost out of the business and make it even stronger.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just add. There's another area where we have a lot of runway that frankly our competition doesn't have because they don't have the Temple opportunity. That's on the procurement side. OCC, we've gotten really good at OCC procurement because th
componenttext: Yes, I would just add. There's another area where we have a lot of runway that frankly our competition doesn't have because they don't have the Temple opportunity. That's on the procurement side. OCC, we've gotten really good at OCC procurement because the capability we didn't have. We are already with fiber opportunities with Temple. And then again on transportation, we've got a huge logistics systems containing container board box of the customers. we got a lot of savings over time we will reload that system and we will flush out more supply chain savings as well.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari of Citi.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: On uncoated free sheet side, I had a question on the Brazilian market. You've seen some strengthening in real which I guess makes the market more attractive for importers and you saw some domestic price erosion in the quarter, and I think some local produ
componenttext: On uncoated free sheet side, I had a question on the Brazilian market. You've seen some strengthening in real which I guess makes the market more attractive for importers and you saw some domestic price erosion in the quarter, and I think some local producers have talked about this year they be been a tougher comp year because they have an election last year. I was wondering if you could just kind of give us some color in the current state of the market in Brazil and sort of what you're seeing in October?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Anthony, this Mark. I think your summary is pretty accurate. The market is actually up demand wise in a decent way. Cut size much better than offset. However, given the current the changes and just the sort of global price levels, the market has attracted
componenttext: Anthony, this Mark. I think your summary is pretty accurate. The market is actually up demand wise in a decent way. Cut size much better than offset. However, given the current the changes and just the sort of global price levels, the market has attracted more imports and that has eaten up some of the growth. So the local producers on to join all of the growth that they might have a couple of years ago. But I think the market is still very healthy and strong and we view it very positively. And we are looking at the fourth quarter that's going to be what we expect seasonally. So far, I think we're pretty pleased with the overall development. It's naive to think a market that's going like that it's never going to attract an import so we try to plan for that in our thinking.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: We did see currency move in our direction during the quarter, Anthony. I mean, if memory serves, roughly around the beginning of August, the real was trading in the mid 1.50s and it weakened almost all the way to 1.90 before going back. So that was some h
componenttext: We did see currency move in our direction during the quarter, Anthony. I mean, if memory serves, roughly around the beginning of August, the real was trading in the mid 1.50s and it weakened almost all the way to 1.90 before going back. So that was some help.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, you got some movement in that way.
componenttext: Right, you got some movement in that way.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Brazil is not just Brazilian one, it's a regional one. We really have a great footprint in Brazil but can serve the regions more cost effectively than anybody else in the region can. So if you look at Brazil by far the biggest market in the region, obviou
componenttext: Brazil is not just Brazilian one, it's a regional one. We really have a great footprint in Brazil but can serve the regions more cost effectively than anybody else in the region can. So if you look at Brazil by far the biggest market in the region, obviously. But our strategy down there is to build a leading position in all the markets and supply those markets out of Brazil and if you think about the World Cup thing in Brazil and Brazil there's, going to be a lot of activity over and above elections for next several years.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: And then maybe switching gears and following up on Mark's question on Illim, does it make sense for brats to maybe expand its footprint in the fluff and sell into China? And maybe what are the potential to there over the near midterm?

componenttext: This is a trial that Illim is experimenting with. I'd say we are a long way from a commercial operations pulp in that part of the world. If we end up there, that will be a good outcome because we will be right on the doorstep of the biggest tissue market in the world there goes be a good outcome for International Paper. But it's a truly early days and if we can make good quality pulp out the that'll be a real breakthrough.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me just make it an overall comment and then Tom Kadien from China I think as global growth slows, the stretching out of capacity additions is a logical thing for companies to do, especially once the capacity plants in excess of market growth. So if yo
componenttext: Let me just make it an overall comment and then Tom Kadien from China I think as global growth slows, the stretching out of capacity additions is a logical thing for companies to do, especially once the capacity plants in excess of market growth. So if you remember a number years ago, when all this pulp capacity was getting Latin America we do know or is going to go. In China growing at the rate it is, having a fiber deficit. Basically, took most of that capacity in a shorter period of time. But global growth outlook is not going negative but it's slowing and I think people adjust their capacity plans accordingly. And tom, would you want to come at about what you're seeing in China?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chip. Clearly, we read and we buy from some of the folks who've slowed up the capacity expansions. I think as a buyer of recycled container board over there, I don't think the slowing capacity is going to impact the market that much. I mean frankly, the b
componenttext: Chip. Clearly, we read and we buy from some of the folks who've slowed up the capacity expansions. I think as a buyer of recycled container board over there, I don't think the slowing capacity is going to impact the market that much. I mean frankly, the biggest suppliers over there have been taking downtime and slowed back for quite a while. And neither has been excess capacity in container board. But they're managing supply and demand pretty well. So I think what we're more sensitive to what we've seen a little bit of price coming down and the recycle container board is the OCC price that goes into China. And that's probably has more impact on pricing of container board in China than on the machines low back. Although certainly, that's probably good thing for the market overall.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, we haven't covered it. I mean basically, we'll update all of those with harder numbers when we report fourth quarter. But I mean you've seen the volatility both on the asset side and on the interest rate side. And so if we market today, we would have
componenttext: No, we haven't covered it. I mean basically, we'll update all of those with harder numbers when we report fourth quarter. But I mean you've seen the volatility both on the asset side and on the interest rate side. And so if we market today, we would have a larger gap than we had at the beginning of the year. And I think that's a big surprise to anyone. It's still manageable and we still feel very confident about how we're managing our pension assets. And we'll update you the fourth quarter but you can -- I think it's pretty reasonable to assume that there will be -- not to the degree we did last year with the $1.2 billion contribution that we made but there will be additional contributions on a smaller scale that will get made overtime.

componenttext: Two. First, just quickly following up on the currency in Illilm. But presumably, after you see that hit in the fourth quarter, that will essentially goes away? And so essentially, it will be Illm reported earnings would then be up by that $55 million the next quarter. Is that the way to think of it?

componenttext: Well, you wouldn't have the $55 million, assuming no movement, you wouldn't have that charge, that's right.

componenttext: Right. Okay. and I know it's kind of petty, but is that an after-tax, the $55 million, is that the way you're going to run it through your -- the P&L or  ...

componenttext: Right. Because we report it on an equity accounting basis, so, yes.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly, you're talking a little bit about OCC waste paper. Where are those costs now and do you have any insights as to where they look like they're trending through the balance of the quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then lastly, you're talking a little bit about OCC waste paper. Where are those costs now and do you have any insights as to where they look like they're trending through the balance of the quarter?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Hey, Mark. This is Carol. Yes, they're trending down some, and I really think that's a result probably less of the U.S. phenomenon because as we look at operating rates at U.S. mill, they've been running fairly strong. And although the OCC mills are going
componenttext: Hey, Mark. This is Carol. Yes, they're trending down some, and I really think that's a result probably less of the U.S. phenomenon because as we look at operating rates at U.S. mill, they've been running fairly strong. And although the OCC mills are going to be the higher cost mills so there will be some pulling back of OCC there. I really think it's probably more of a China effect of just a slowing down at the point in time. So they are trending down some. Boy, if I could predict OCC, the price is out, 3, 4 months, that would be a great crystal ball. I don't have that. But I do think they're trending down and we'll just see where they go.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: And where they are today versus say the third quarter average?

componenttext: I would probably not comment on it today because folks are going to publish in a few days and I might get it wrong because it's unclear. But I would say that it's going to definitely move down from October to November.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011

componenttext: I wondered if we could go back to Brazil for a minute or 2. I think that you've got that decision to make on the second machine down there, at some point, I wondered if you could just update us on that, particularly in light of the strength of the currency down there? And then also talk to us about any plans for thoughts about in the packaging business in Brazil or elsewhere in Latin America?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I will let Mark talk about the second paper machine and then I will just comment about packaging markets.
componenttext: Well, I will let Mark talk about the second paper machine and then I will just comment about packaging markets.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, we have a couple of years before we have to make the final decision on that additional capacity. And obviously the way we're thinking about that is based on market growth and the other -- the dynamics to how that market serve if we need the addition
componenttext: Mark, we have a couple of years before we have to make the final decision on that additional capacity. And obviously the way we're thinking about that is based on market growth and the other -- the dynamics to how that market serve if we need the additional capacity for not only Brazil, as John said earlier, but for the greater Latin American region, then that would be an attractive thing for us to do. But we do have a little more time on that and we are monitoring the market. The currency is obviously a factor. But we would make a decision like that obviously for the long-term.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think that's the important point, Mark, is in the about long-term. It's a 20-year investments, you don't want to make a spot currency at the point in time and currency in Brazil from $1.50 to $3. Smart to figure out what it's going to be in 2025 but
componenttext: And I think that's the important point, Mark, is in the about long-term. It's a 20-year investments, you don't want to make a spot currency at the point in time and currency in Brazil from $1.50 to $3. Smart to figure out what it's going to be in 2025 but the investment we make will be around to 2025. So we could be dealing with that, at the time comes. from a packaging perspective, we will have a stronger packaging presence in Latin America with Mexico, we got one box plant in Chile. We like to be in the business, both in the region unbleached packaging in Latin America and if the right opportunity against all that valuation, create value for International Paper, we will consider it. If it's not the right valuation, it's a place in the world we'd like to be but won't be.

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And John, can we just -- with what Tom Kadien is working on now in India, you've kind of, you're hitting all the bricks at this point, and I wondered if you could just give us thought on how you'll allocate capital in all of those different countries? And
componenttext: And John, can we just -- with what Tom Kadien is working on now in India, you've kind of, you're hitting all the bricks at this point, and I wondered if you could just give us thought on how you'll allocate capital in all of those different countries? And then when we think about your CapEx budget, how much of that is really going to be focused, just in ballpark terms, in the U.S. and Western Europe? And how much of it will be allocated to some of the emerging markets that you're in?

headline: International Paper Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a very good question and I think we've talked about a balanced allocation of cash and that includes our approach to CapEx balance allocation of cash. Cash back to shareowners, cash reinvested in our existing business, a strong balance sheet a
componenttext:
Well, that's a very good question and I think we've talked about a balanced allocation of cash and that includes our approach to CapEx balance allocation of cash. Cash back to shareowners, cash reinvested in our existing business, a strong balance sheet and selectively reinvesting. Russia is a great example of being able to do that aggressively on, not on IP's balance sheet but on the joint ventures. But you've got that capacity. India, we are going to need to get in there and figure out how to grow with the market, both in paper and packaging. And we are going to continue to spend only on cost reduction in North America. And on regulatory capital, we got some of that coming down the pipe with so. We are going to force -- there's going to continue to be capital less and we're going to skew the capital to where we think the strategic investment is going to be made but we'll keep our North American, the right assets in North America competitive and modern, and I think we've been able to do that with this $1 billion spending over the last couple of years and going forward for the next couple on average. With Temple, we have little more capital spending. so we'll be updating you on kind of the next 5 years how you should think about CapEx relative to depreciation, but in some places of the world, it will be a lot higher, in some places of the world, it will be a lot lower.
Okay. Well, listen, let me just wrap it up by saying International Paper has been pretty pleased about the fourth quarter, it was on flat revenues, it was third quarter rather quite strong relative to where it had been. And we're pretty positive, and say, quite positive how we're looking at in 2012 and even though the macro environment kind of feels to us like it's going to be more of the same, what we have on our plate, we think International Paper best days are still ahead of us. So thanks for tuning in on the call and we'll talk to you next quarter
